## Page 1

## CHAPTER X3-1

PARTS INQUIRY

### Introduction

Parts Inquiry allows you to search for and view Parts are in your inventory and to
use communications to inquire on parts from the manufacturer. You can also view
part information supplied in the manufacturer's price book for parts not in your
inventory, and equivalent parts from Bearing Interchange. This job is inquiry
only. To make changes, use X3-2, PARTS POSTING & MAINTENANCE,
Major features (such as Cores, Quantity Break Pricing, Cross-referencing),
pricing and availability, and field definitions can be found in CHAPTER X3-2,
PARTS POSTING & MAINTENANCE,

 

NOTE
Command keys and Function keys are the same. The S/36 environment uses
[Cmd); the AS/400 uses [F].

From Point of Sale (X5-1), [Cmd23] comes directly to Parts Inquiry. The

Information screen for the part number on the detail line, if any, is displayed.
Parts cannot be retrieved from Parts Inquiry back to Point of Sale.

You may search by part number by entering a text string after the "?". Example:
In the part number field, enter 7410094. Except that the text string begins with a
"2" the resulting search would be equivalent to a search by part number described
below.

Positional search by part number

Once the Parts Search Window is displayed, you can perform a search by part
number by entering a text string and press [Enter]. You will be positioned in the
Parts Index to the first part that begins with text string you just entered. This is
called a positional search.

Non-positional text search

Alternately, if you precede the text string with a"*" the computer will display all
parts that contain the text string you entered in any position. For example "*10"
would find 10551, 911002, and, 6510. This is called a non-positional search.

Search by description

You may also perform a search by description. This works in the same way as the
parts search, except you press {Cmd5] instead of [Enter] after the text string has
been keyed in.

### Sales History Screen

The information on the Sales History Screen is updated by transactions at Point of
Sale and by transactions from the Transaction Screen at Parts Posting &
Maintenance. Sales History is automatically updated when Parts End of Day is
run. It can be updated manually when you are adding parts to your DIS inventory
for which you already have some history. See Chapter X3-2, PARTS POSTING
AND MAINTENANCE.

Sales History is kept by the system for 3 years. When Parts End of Year is run,
the system gets rid of all history over 24 months and leaves room for the new
year. This is something to remember when you request a phase-out or sales return
based on history.

Sales: A sale of 5 widgets to one person is recorded as | call, 5 pieces.

Lost Sales: A lost sale where one person wanted 5 widgets is recorded as 1 call
and 5 pieces. The only difference in the way lost sales are recorded is where they
are summarized on the Parts Management Report (X36-2) where there is a special
category, "Lost sales”.

### Supersession Screen

 

The Supersession screen shows a forward supersession chain for the part. If
supersession information is in the price book, the information is added to the part
record when the part is added to inventory. The supersession information can also
be added manually at Parts Posting and Maintenance (X3- 2).

Only the parts forward in the chain will display on the screen. For example, ABC
Company began with a MAN part of A1250. It was superseded by A1251. A1251
was superseded by A1252 and A1252 was superseded by A1253.

### Remanufactured Parts

New parts reference the remanufactured (reman) part. Reman parts show prices of
the reman part and its primary core and reference the primary core part number.
Primary cores reference alternate cores, if any. For more information on reman
parts, see chapter X38-1, CONFIGURE VENDOR/CLASS.

### Supersession

Supersession information is available in the following options:
- Parts Inquiry (X3-1)

- Parts Posting & Maintenance (X3-2)

- Display/Print/Change Price Book (X37-3)

- Point of Sale Detail Line (X5-1)

- Part Availability (Cmd12 from X5-1)

- Electronic Parts Catalogs

Except for Display/Print/Change Price Book (X37-3) and Electronic Parts
Catalogs, backward supersession is not handled. The DIS system attempts to sell
all parts from inventory in a forward chain and displays the last part in the chain
so it can be ordered, if necessary. The Electronic Parts Catalog skips intermediate
parts and displays only 1 level of backward and 1 level of forward supersession
(the last part in the chain).

Parts Inquiry (X3-1)

The Supersede code "S” means the part has been superseded by a single part. "M"
means the part has been superseded by multiple parts, only the first
(alphabetically) is displayed. This information is updated by price tape update.
Parts In Inventory

If the entire chain is in inventory, it is displayed at F7=Supersession when the
original part number is entered. If a superseding part is entered, the chain is
displayed from that part forward. You must press F5=Division to check
availability for a part in other divisions.

Parts Not In Inventory

If the original part number is entered, the chain is revealed from the price book

one number at a time in a message at the bottom of the screen. If a superseding
part is entered, the chain is displayed from that part forward.

Parts Posting & Maintenance (X3-2) C

Parts In Inventory

Supersession information can be added to any part manually. This is overwritten
when inventory is updated from a price tape or price book unless the part is ina
class flagged as non-updateable (automatic pricing = N) in Configure
Vendor/Class (X38-1). In the absence of a price book, this information is used by
POS to chain to superseding parts.

Parts Not In Inventory

Parts may be added from the price book from any point in a chain. No
supersession information is retrieved, only pricing and the return code. There is
no way to know how many superseding parts there are or to go directly to the end
of the chain.

Display/Print Price Book (X37-3)

The price book displays backward (supersedes) and forward (superseded by)
chains. The "M" indicator seems to mean the part supersedes many different parts
and does not correspond to the "M" indicator used in Parts Posting &
Maintenance, which means the part is superseded by multiple parts (kit).

Point of Sale Detail Screen

Point of Sale uses both local inventory and the price book to sell the first available
part in a forward chain, and always displays the last part number in the chain, A
part that has been superseded by multiple parts shows simply *MULTIPLE*.

Part In Inventory

Availability information is displayed. If the request cannot be filled by the first
part entered, the next part in the chain with available quantity will be displayed on
the comment line. After all available parts have been sold, the last part in the
chain can be ordered.

Part Not in Inventory

Regardless of where you start in a chain, the last part in the chain is displayed on
the comment line. If it is not possible to order the part you enter, such as AA1117,
you will receive an “Invalid part” message, and the most current part will be
displayed on the comment line. If it is possible to order the part you entered, it
will be displayed on the detail line with a "P" priority code, but the most current
part number will be displayed on the comment line.


PARTS. X3-1 « PARTS INQUIRY 23

 

Part Availability

Part in Inventory
All superseding parts in the chain that are in inventory are displayed whether they
will be needed to meet the request or not.

Part Not In Inventory

Part Availability searches local inventory, other divisions, and the price book. All
parts in the forward supersession chain will be displayed. If the original part
requested is in the requesting division's inventory but not available, it will show
"NOT OK.” Parts located in the price book will be indented and show "NOT
OK/PRC BOOK." If you left-justify the parts and press [Enter] again, the system
will search other divisions for the superseding part and display availability
information. You will be able to order the last part in the chain, if necessary. The
system will repeat the quantity, which is adjusted manually as you decide what
parts to sell.

Electronic Parts Catalog

As of 11/5/96, the DIS interface to the parts catalog displays 1 level of backward
supersession and the last part(s) in the forward chain (1 level). If the parts listed
are in the dealer's inventory, availability and bin location are displayed. No
intermediate parts are shown, regardless of whether the part is in the dealer's local
inventory or not. Multiple "Superseded by” part numbers indicate a kit. Multiple
"Supersedes" may be from a kit to one part or simply separate parts that have
been superseded by the same part.

Multiple supersession is the most difficult because manufacturers do not make it
clear whether a part is superseded by 3 different single parts or by a kit consisting
of 3 parts. In some cases, the original part number is superseded by several
different part numbers, any one of which can be used to replace the original part.
In other cases, the original part is superseded by a kit composed of several
different part numbers, all of which are required to do the job of the 1 original
part number. In either case, the DIS Business System displays "*MULTIPLE*" in
the "Super." field at Point of Sale. If possible, use the comment field on the Parts
Posting & Maintenance screen to store all part numbers that are required for
supersession.

 

Stand-alone parts catalogs (without the DIS interface) display only the last part(s)
in a forward supersession chain.

### Supersession

Supersession information is available in the following options:
- Parts Inquiry (X3-1)

- Parts Posting & Maintenance (X3-2)

- Display/Print/Change Price Book (X37-3)

- Point of Sale Detail Line (X5-1)

- Part Availability (Cmd12 from X5-1)

- Electronic Parts Catalogs

Except for Display/Print/Change Price Book (X37-3) and Electronic Parts
Catalogs, backward supersession is not handled. The DIS system attempts

to sell all parts from inventory in a forward chain and displays the last part

in the chain so it can be ordered, if necessary. The Electronic Parts Catalog (
skips intermediate parts and displays only 1 level of backward and 1 level

of forward supersession (the last part in the chain).

Parts Inquiry (X3-1)

The Supersede code "S" means the part has been superseded by a single
part. "M" means the part has been superseded by multiple parts, only the
first (alphabetically) is displayed. This information is updated by price
tape update.

Parts in Inventory

If the entire chain is in inventory, it is displayed at F7=Supersession when
the original part number is entered. If a superseding part is entered, the
chain is displayed from that part forward. You must press F5=Division to
check availability for a part in other divisions.

Parts In Inventory

overwritten when inventory is updated from a price tape or price book

by) chains. The "M" indicator seems to mean the part supersedes many
different parts and does not correspond to the "M" indicator used in Parts
Posting & Maintenance, which means the part is superseded by multiple
parts (kit).

### Sales History Screen

The information on the Sales History Screen is updated by transactions at
Point of Sale and by transactions from the Transaction Screen at Parts
Posting & Maintenance. Sales History is automatically updated when Parts
End of Day is run. It can be updated manually when you are adding parts
to your DIS inventory for which you already have some history. See
Chapter X3-2, PARTS POSTING AND MAINTENANCE.

Sales History is kept by the system for 3 years. When Parts End of Year is
run, the system gets rid of all history over 24 months and leaves room for
the new year. This is something to remember when you request a
phase-out or sales return based on history.

Sales: A sale of 5 widgets to one person is recorded as 1 call, 5 pieces.
Lost Sales: A lost sale where one person wanted 5 widgets is recorded as
1 call and 5 pieces. The only difference in the way lost sales are recorded
is where they are summarized on the Parts Management Report (X36-2)
where there is a special category, "Lost sales”.

## CHAPTER X3-2

PARTS POSTING & MAINTENANCE

### Introduction

Parts Posting & Maintenance could be used without Point of Sale as a
complete inventory control system. It replaces the parts card file which is
used in a manual system. New parts can be added, information can be
updated, and sales history records can be kept. Transactions recorded in
Parts Posting & Maintenance are summarized on the Parts Management
Report (X36-2).

When the Point of Sale application has been installed, most inventory
control functions are handled automatically, so that Parts Posting &
Maintenance is used most often to correct segmentation errors, to change
information on existing part records, and to make minor quantity
adjustments to inventory.

These are the options within Parts Posting & Maintenance. Only the
command keys listed on the screen are available:

Cmd1 -End job
Cmd2 -Information Screen

Cmd3 -Sales History Screen

Cmmd4 -Transaction Screen

Cmd5 -Source of Supply Screen
Cmd11-XRef (Cross-reference) Screen
Cmd13-Notebook

In this chapter there is a section for each screen, where examples and field
limits are provided. The last section, WHAT CAN GO WRONG AND
WHAT TO DO, covers the most frequent problems with parts files.

Note the field on the right side of the screen labeled "Core code" (under
“Qty.Break"). This 1-character field is user-defined and accommodates
any alpha-numeric character. When you sell a part with a core code at
Point of Sale, the system "looks at” the first 18 characters of the comment
line. If it finds a valid part number there, the system places both parts on
the sales document--the part with the core code plus the part number in the
first 18 characters of the comment line.

The only restriction is that both part numbers must have the same vendor
code. This feature is available on the detail screen at Point of Sale and on
the Part Availability screen (Cmd12). Both setup and sales will be
illustrated in this chapter.

To keep up with parts that have core codes, a new option has been added
to the Parts Report Menu (X3-6): Core Inventory Pad. On this report only
parts with core codes are listed, and you can choose to exclude up to 6
codes. In contrast, the Parts Inventory Pad option (X36-1) lists all parts;
however, it also allows you to exclude up to 6 core codes.

To keep track of who has paid core charges and who has received refunds,
you can use a new option, Part Sales History, which is option 7 on the
Point of Sale Invoicing Menu. The same option is available on the
Additional Options Menu (Cmd11 from Point of Sale). For more
information, see CHAPTER X5-7, PART SALES HISTORY.

New parts reference the remanufactured (reman) part. Reman parts show
prices of the reman part and its primary core and reference the primary
core part number. Primary cores reference alternate cores, if any. For more
information on reman parts, see chapter X38-1, CONFIGURE
VENDOR/CLASS.

Point of Sale

On the Point of Sale detail screen, all the salesperson needs to do is enter
the sales code and part number for the battery. When s/he presses [Enter],
the system adds the core charge to the document automatically.

When the core is returned, the salesperson will simply sell the core charge
part number with a quantity of -1.

Reports

Parts Inventory Pad (X36-1). The selection screen allows you to exclude
up to 6 core codes; however, a Parts Inventory Pad prints all parts for the
Vendor/Class selected.

Core Inventory Pad (X36-20). The selection screen is the same as the Parts
Inventory Pad above; however, the Core Inventory Pad prints only parts
that have core codes. You can exclude up to 6 core codes.

Advanced Techniques

Now that you have learned how to use core codes for standard core
charges, let's consider other ways to use the same feature. You can build
up "kits" of parts: Part 1 points to Part 2 which points to Part 3, etc. Every
time the system encounters a part with a core code, it will sell the part
number(s) on the comment line, making it possible to link up to 40 parts
together for a "kit". The maximum number of 40 is set to prevent a core
part being looped back to itself if the chain were endless.

For example, you might have a frame that is always sold with a set of
brackets and screws. By using a core code on the frame and the brackets’
part number in the comment field, you can have the brackets placed on the
same document. Because the bracket part number also has a core code and

Disk Space

As with any extra feature, particularly one that pertains to many records,
you need to be aware of disk space. Cross-referencing 40 parts requires 1
block. Cross-referencing 10,000 parts takes 250 blocks of disk space.

To estimate how many blocks you need to use X32XRF, divide the
number of part numbers in your inventory by 40.

Each part can be cross-referenced to as many as 26 other part numbers,
which incorporate vendor code and quantity. For example, vendor AMI,
part C90921, quantity 4, can be cross-referenced to "C94" while quantity 6
is cross-referenced to "C96."

The indexes operate like quick codes except they can be longer--up to 24

Price Books

Parts information may be kept in two places: in the parts files associated
with your User ID, which are known as your inventory files, and in a large
file known as a price book. A price book is separate from your inventory
and contains all of the parts the manufacturer supplies on a price tape.

If you have room on your disk for one or more price books, they can be a
big help at Parts Posting & Maintenance. Information from a price book
can be added directly to your parts inventory files, which saves a lot of
typing and ensures accuracy. Chapter X37-4, Create/Update Price Book
has the information you need to estimate the amount of disk space
required for a particular price book.

Quantity Break Pricing

What is Quantity Break Pricing? Many manufacturers receive quantity
break pricing from their suppliers, price breaks for buying in volume. The
price depends upon the quantity. For example, there may be one price if
they buy from I to 9 of an item, and a lower price if they buy 10 or more,
and an even lower price if they buy 50 or more. There may be several
ranges with corresponding price decreases. Manufacturers may choose to
pass these savings on to the dealers. Dealers, in turn, may want to pass the
savings on to customers who buy in large quantities.

Advantages of Quantity Break Pricing: Selling parts in large volumes
heips to reduce your costs. The parts do not have to be counted or handled
as often. Storage costs are decreased. Up front, the parts may not cost as
much because of the large quantity discounts received from the
manufacturer.

PARTS INVENTORY

## X3-2. PARTS POSTING & MAINTENANCE

 

What is required: A price book with quantity break pricing is required.
Quantity break pricing is furnished by some manufacturers, usually on a
separate price tape.

Identifying the Customers: With the DIS Special Feature, Quantity Break
Pricing, you can identify the customers who buy in volume (Receivables

Maintenance, X1 1-2). This information will be relayed to Point of Sale, so
that the customer may receive quantity break pricing on appropriate parts.

Identifying the Parts: The price tape sent by the manufacturer will
identify parts with quantity break prices and the breaks offered on specific
quantities (ranges).

Quantity break pricing information is kept in the price book, not in your

inventory files. If the price book is removed, quantity break information (
will be lost.

### Supersession

Supersession information is available in the following options:
- Parts Inquiry (X3-1)

- Parts Posting & Maintenance (X3-2)

- Display/Print Price Book (X37-3)

- Point of Sale Detail Line (X5-1)

- Part Availability (Cmd12 from X5-1)

- Electronic Parts Catalogs

Except for Display/Print Price Book (X37-3) and Electronic Parts
Catalogs, backward supersession is not handled. The DIS system attempts
to sell all parts from inventory in a forward chain and displays the last part
in the chain so it can be ordered, if necessary. The Electronic Parts Catalog
skips intermediate parts and displays only 1} level of backward and 1 level
of forward supersession (the last part in the chain).

Parts Inquiry (X3-1)

 

The Supersede code "S" means the part has been superseded by a single
part. "M" means the part has been superseded by multiple parts, only the
first (alphabetically) is displayed. This information is updated by price
tape update.

Parts In Inventory

If the entire chain is in inventory, it is displayed at F7=Supersession when
the original part number is entered. If a superseding part is entered, the
chain is displayed from that part forward. You must press F5=Division to
check availability for a part in other divisions.

PARTS INVENTORY


[| X3-2 PARTS POSTING & MAINTENANCE

Parts Not In Inventory

If the original part number is entered, the chain is revealed from the price
book one number at a time in a message at the bottom of the screen. If a
superseding part is entered, the chain is displayed from that part forward.

Parts Posting & Maintenance (X3-2)

Parts In Inventory

Supersession information can be added to any part manually. This is
overwritten when inventory is updated from a price tape or price book
unless the part is in a class flagged as non-updatable (automatic pricing =
N) in Configure Vendor/Class (X38-1). In the absence of a price book, this
information is used by POS to chain to superseding parts.

Parts Not fn Inventory

Parts may be added from the price book from any point in a chain. No
supersession information is retrieved, only pricing and the return code.
There is no way to know how many superseding parts there are or to go
directly to the end of the chain.

Display/Print Price Book (X37-3)

The price book displays backward (supersedes) and forward (superseded
by) chains. The "M" indicator seems to mean the part supersedes many
different parts and does not correspond to the "M" indicator used in Parts
Posting & Maintenance, which means the part is superseded by multiple
parts (kit).


Point of Sale Detail Screen

Point of Sale uses both local inventory and the price book to sell the first
available part in a forward chain, and always displays the last part number
in the chain. A part that has been superseded by multiple parts shows
simply *MULTIPLE*.

Part In Inventory

Availability information is displayed. If the request cannot be filled by the
first part entered, the next part in the chain with available quantity will be
displayed on the comment line. After all available parts have been sold,
the last part in the chain can be ordered.

Part Not In Inventory

Regardless of where you start in a chain, the last part in the chain is
displayed on the comment line. If it is not possible to order the part you
enter, such as AA1117, you will receive an “Invalid part" message, and the
most current part will be displayed on the comment line. If it is possible to
order the part you entered, it will be displayed on the detail line with a "P"
priority code, but the most current part number will be displayed on the
comment line.

PARTS INVENTORY


[=| X3-2 PARTS POSTING & MAINTENANCE 7

Part Availability

Part in Inventory
All superseding parts in the chain that are in inventory are displayed
whether they will be needed to meet the request or not.

Part Not In Inventory

Part Availability searches local inventory, other divisions, and the price

book. Al! parts in the forward supersession chain will be displayed. If the

original part requested is in the requesting division's inventory but not

available, it will show "NOT OK.” Parts located in the price book will be

indented and show "NOT OK/PRC BOOK.” If you left-justify the parts

and press [Enter] again, the system wiil search other divisions for the

superseding part and display availability information. You will be able to (
order the last part in the chain, if necessary. The system will repeat the

quantity, which is adjusted manually as you decide what parts to sell.

Electronic Parts Catalog

As of 11/5/96, the DIS interface to the parts catalog displays 1 level of
backward supersession and the last part(s) in the forward chain (1 level). If
the parts listed are in the dealer's inventory, availability and bin location
are displayed. No intermediate parts are shown, regardless of whether the
part is in the dealer's local inventory or not. Multiple “Superseded by" part
numbers indicate a kit. Multiple "Supersedes" may be from a kit to one
part or simply separate parts that have been superseded by the same part.

Multiple supersession is the most difficult because manufacturers do not

make it clear whether a part is superseded by 3 different single parts or by
a kit consisting of 3 parts. In some cases, the original part number is

used to replace the original part. In other cases, the original part is

case, the DIS Business System displays "*MULTIPLE*" in the "Super."
field at Point of Sale. If possible, use the comment field on the Parts

Stand-alone parts catalogs (without the DIS interface) display only the last

(A) Add Record

Add Record is used to add a new part record to your inventory. It is not
used to add to the on hand quantity of parts already in your inventory (see
Plus, Receipt, or Transfer). These records are added to the "INVENTORY
ADJUSTMENTS - Part Adjustments" section of the Parts Management
Report (X36-2).

Adding Parts from PP&M

These steps are required to add a part in Parts Posting & Maintenance:

 

Add Record on the Transaction Screen.
Enter information on the Information Screen.

 

 

 

 

 

These steps are optional:

O Record On hand quantities on the Transaction Screen.

O Record Sales History on the Sales History Screen.

O Set up Source of Supply vendors on the Source of Supply Screen.

The main advantage in Parts Posting & Maintenance is that you can use a
price book to bring in current, accurate information about the parts.

Adding Parts From Initial Parts Data Entry

If you do not have a price book and if you have several parts to add, it is
probably faster to add parts from Initial Parts Data Entry (Menu X68-5).

In Initial Parts Data Entry only one screen is required to add the part to
inventory, record information, on hand quantity, and sales history.

For your convenience, there are other places within the DIS System where
you can choose to add parts to inventory, including Correct Stock Order
(X341-2), Correct Order Before Receiving (X342-1), Point of Sale (X5-1),
and Priority Orders (X5-3).

Segment Markers

To Add a new part record or Change an existing record, segment markers
must be correctly placed in the part number. If the number is not too
complicated, you might be able to look at a similar part number which is
already in inventory and figure it out.

Otherwise, you must check the vendor configuration. You may use a Con-
figuration Report (X38-2) or look at the vendor in Configure Vendor/Class (
(38-1). What you are looking for are the segment sizes.

There can be up to 18 characters in a part number. These 18 characters can
be in 1 to 4 segments. To add or change a part number, segment markers
must be placed between the segments. This is how the computer knows
how to display or print the part numbers so that they look like the part
numbers you see in the manufacturer's book.

The total of the segment sizes may go as high as 22 even though the part
number cannot be over 18 characters.

Examples of configurations using the maximum segment sizes are:

06 06 06 04
02 10 10
04 18

08 08 06

(L) Post Lost Sale

Post Lost Sale is used to record a sale which was lost because the part was
not in stock. It increases the number of calls and pieces in sales history just
as if the part had been sold. The demand is increased so the part can be
considered for a Suggested Stock Order. The Lost Sales Report (X36-11)
can help you decide when it is time to reevaluate stocking procedures. In
addition, the dollar value of lost sales are tracked on the Parts
Management Report (X36-2, page 2, LOST SALES).

If you are using Point of Sale, record lost sales at invoicing by entering an
"L" in the priority code field on the parts detail line. The part will not
appear on the invoice. See Point of Sale Reference Section.

This example illustrates how to record a lost sale on 4 widgets. One
customer wanied 4 widgets, which were out of stock. She went to a com-
petitor who always stocks widgets. The sale was lost. Calls will be
increased by 1. Pieces will be increased by 4. Since sales history is
updated when Parts End of Day is run, this change will not show
immediately on the Sales History Screen.

What About Oil, Chain, and Screws?

Note:

The techniques described in this section were developed before the
addition of Core Codes, which could also be used effectively in these
Situations. See Cores.

 

Here are some hints about dealing with things like oil, chain, and boxes of
screws which each have a part number from the manufacturer, but which
you sell in smaller quantities. In this example we will consider a 55 gallon
drum of oil which you then sell in quarts, gallons, and 5 gallon containers.
The same principle applies to chain which is bought in 200 foot lengths
and sold by the foot, or screws which come in boxes of 100 but are sold
individually.

### Sales History Screen

The information on the Sales History Screen is updated by transactions at
Point of Sale and by transactions from the Transaction Screen at Parts
Posting & Maintenance. Sales History is automatically updated when Parts
End of Day is run. Usually it is updated manually only when you are
adding parts to your DIS inventory for which you already have some
history.

Sales History is kept by the system for 3 years. When Parts End of Year is
Tun, the system gets rid of all history over 24 months and leaves room for
the new year. This is something to remember when you request a phase-
out or sales return based on history.

### What Can Go Wrong And What To Do

For many problems in parts files the solution is to run Parts End of Month.
It is the DIS equivalent of take 2 aspirin and call me in the morning.

Parts files are extremely large. Every part in your inventory has informa-
tion in more than one file. "Pointers" in one file point to the corresponding
part information in other files. Because of the sheer size and complexity of
these files, plus the wear and tear of daily use, it is not uncommon for the
pointers to get mixed up and point to the wrong places. The results may be
quite strange, but there is no need for alarm.

Parts End of Month reorganizes the parts files and straightens out the

pointers. It is OK to run Parts End of Month more than once a month, and (
it is equally important to run it at least once a month.

## CHAPTER X3-3

PARTS INVENTORY ADJUSTMENT MENU

### Introduction

The Inventory Adjustment Menu provides an easy way to conduct a
physical inventory with an audit trail. This feature promotes a perpetual
inventory system which eliminates the costly, often inaccurate, and always
inconvenient annual inventory event.

### Overview

The Inventory Adjustment Menu contains the following jobs:

X33-1 Parts Inventory Adjustment
Allows adjustments to On Hand or Available Quantities
and Bin Locations of parts on the Parts Inventory
Adjustment Report. Establishes the Last Count date from
session date in effect.

X33-2 Parts Inventory Adjustment Report
Prints a report of parts to be inventoried. The report may be
in order by bin location or by part number. Available or On
Hand quantities may be printed on this report if desired.

X33-3 Parts Exception Report
Lists parts which were on the Inventory Adjustment Report
but which were skipped during the Inventory Adjustment
job.

X33-4 Parts Inventory Freeze
Use Parts Inventory Freeze to take a snapshot of your parts
inventory files prior to a major change, such as Inventory
Adjustment or a Price Tape Update.

## X3-3 PARTS INVENTORY ADJUSTMENT MENU

| No parts or point of sale jobs can be running when the freeze is

 

33-5 Parts Inventory Variation Report
Select Parts Inventory Variation Report to print a list of the
differences (variations) between the work file created by
Parts Inventory Freeze (X33-4) and your current parts
inventory files.

You will find the "How to Run" information in each individual chapter.

The next section in this chapter provides more detailed explanation of how (
the DIS Parts Inventory System works and how you can use it most

efficiently.

At the end of the chapter, you'll find checklists for organizing and
accomplishing the physical inventory.

### The Inventory Process

This section explains the steps involved in taking inventory.
Get a List of the Parts to be Inventoried.

Run the Parts Inventory Adjustment Report (X33-2). A portion of the
inventory is selected. This may be in order by bin location or part number.
The idea is to select a manageable number of bins or parts, perhaps only
what can be handled in one day by one person.

Example:
Bins A1 through B22 or parts A12345 through A67890 for vendor ABC.

Note:

If your bins begin with numbers (1-12, 2H-30), and you want the

report by bin location, request the Compressed version. The procedure
for Expanded is looking for a letter first, and if there is none, the
results may be strange.

 

The report (list) will be printed as requested. More than one copy may be
requested if more than one person will be counting. It may be single or
double spaced. Available or on hand quantities may be printed or not, just
as you prefer.


 

Advantages of a Blind Count

When the Quantity is not printed on the Inventory Adjustment Report, it is
called a Blind Count.


here are 2 advantages:

a The actual count is more likely to be accurate, since no estimate
can be made based on the report.

If the status changes from the time the report is printed until the
actual count is made, the quantity counted and the "Available"
field on screen will be the same.

 

 

 

 

The Inventory Adjustment File (

Calling for the Inventory Adjustment Report creates a file, u.JJMd (u =
your User ID and d = your division code). There can be only one of these
files per division. If an u.IJMd file already exists you will be asked
whether you want it to be deleted.

The Inventory Adjustment Report will be a picture of the parts as they
were at the time the report was requested. The file, u.IJMd is updated by
activity at Point of Sale or PPM.

Two Ways to Count Inventory
Available Count
Available quantities display in PPM (X3-2) and Parts Inquiry (X3- 1).

Available quantities are the amount of the parts that are available for sale.
If you are counting available quantities, it is assumed that only parts that

RELEASE 2.1 LO


 

are available for sale are in the bin. A will call area exists where all parts
that are reserved have been placed. Also, it is assumed that all priority
ordered parts have been identified.

On Hand Count

On hand quantities are displayed in PPM (X3-2) and Parts Inquiry (X3-1).
If you are counting on hand quantities, the basic assumption is that all
parts are in the bin. No parts are located in other parts of the dealership.

Make the Adjustments

Run Parts Inventory Adjustment (X33-1). This is the job in which
adjustments are actually made.

There may be some parts which are on the report but which, for some
reason, are not counted. There may be questions concerning the actual
available or on hand quantity. These parts may be skipped. They will
appear on the Inventory Exception Report. For details, see the section,
When to Skip a Part.

What to Look For

Since the purpose of inventory adjustment is to reconcile what the
computer thinks you have with what you actually have, you are concerned
with parts where the Available or On hand counted does not match what's
in the Available or On hand field on screen.

Changing the Available or On Hand field on screen is the same as Plus or
Minus at Parts Posting & Maintenance. The change is listed in the same
place on the Parts End of Day Report. The only difference is that the
Application (App) is IVJ if it is done from Inventory Adjustment instead


 

of PPM for Parts Posting & Maintenance.

Also, Inventory Adjustment will update the Last Count Date displayed at
PPM or Parts Inquiry.

When To Make An Adjustment - Available Count

Example:

In Bin Al there are 4 widgets (Or available counted = 4). In the Inventory
Adjustment job the Available field on screen is 3 widgets. This widget is
not on a Priority Order. This calls for an adjustment.

Available on screen is changed to 4. On Hand will simultaneously be
increased by 1 widget. This is the same as Plus in Parts Posting &
Maintenance. The Parts End of Day Report will show an inventory
adjustment (App = IVJ). The next Parts Pad will reflect the change. The
audit trail is intact.

For details on when you should not make an adjustment, see the section,
WHAT CAN GO WRONG AND WHAT TO DO.

When to Make An Adjustment - On Hand Count

Example:

In Bin B200, there are 6 widgets. In the Inventory Adjustment job, the
"Available" field on screen displays 5 widgets. No parts are located
anywhere in the dealership. This calls for an adjustment. On hand,
displayed in the On Hand field on screen, is changed to 6. Available will
simultaneously be increased by 1 widget. This is the same as Plus in Parts

RELEASE 2.1 LL


 

Posting & Maintenance. The Parts End of Day Report will show an
inventory adjustment (App = I'VJ). The next Parts Pad will reflect the
change. The audit trail is intact.

Por details on when you should not make an adjustment, see the section,
WHAT CAN GO WRONG AND WHAT TO DO.

Reviewing a List of the Exceptions

Run the Parts Inventory Exception Report (X33-3). This report is run after
the adjustments have been made to most of the parts. The parts which were
skipped will be on this report. Questions about these parts should be
resolved. Then the Inventory Adjustment job should be run again to
include them in this count. The Inventory Adjustment job allows you to
skip around, so it doesn't take long to go back in.

For help in resolving questions, see the section WHAT CAN GO
WRONG AND WHAT TO DO.

### What Are The Basic Assumptions?

To understand how to use the DIS Inventory System most efficiently, you
must understand its basic assumptions and act accordingly.

Timing is critical. The most important thing is to keep the time spans from
running the report to the counting to making the adjustments at a
minimum. Mark the bins which are being counted. Report any activity to
the person who is doing the counting. Since the DIS System is so easy to
do in small chunks, this usually is not difficult, and questions can be
resolved quickly.

Decide to adjust Available or On hand quantities. Remember the
assumptions: (

Available= If adjusting available quantities, only those parts available
for sale are still in the bins. All reserved parts have been
pulled from the bin and priority order parts identified.

OnHand= All parts are in the bin. Reservations have not been pulled.

You have identified any parts on reservation but not in the
bin.

### Adjusting Available Quantities

Assumption 1: Only Available Parts are Left in the Bins

The assumption is that only the parts that are actually available are in the
bins. This means that parts which are reserved (on open repair orders or

RELEASE 2.1 LL


counter tickets) have been taken out of the bins and put somewhere else.
The basic formula is: AVAILABLE = ON HAND - RESERVATIONS.

Here is an example of a widget as seen at Parts Inquiry before it is put on
an open repair order:

BEFORE Available..: 1
REPAIR Reserve R/O: 0
ORDER Reserve C/T: 0
On Hand....: 1
PTY qty....: 0

As soon as the widget is placed on an open repair order, its status changes:

ON OPEN Available..: 0
REPAIR Reserve R/O: 1
ORDER Reserve C/T: 0
On Hand....: 1
PTY qty....: 0

The formula is correct. Available (0) = On Hand (1) - Reservations (1).

If inventory is taken at this point, the system expects that the widget has
been taken out of the bin. The person who is counting will find zero
widgets available. If the Available Quantity is printed on the Inventory
Adjustment Report, it will be zero. The Available Quantity on screen in
the Inventory Adjustment job will also be zero.

If the Repair Order is closed in the meantime, the Available Quantity does


 

not change:
AFTER Available..: 0
REPAIR Reserve R/O: 0
ORDER Reserve C/T: 0
On Hand....: 0
PTY qty....: 0

There is no problem.

What You Can Do

If you do not usually remove parts from the bins as soon as they are placed

on a repair order or a counter ticket, develop a system which will serve the t
same purpose. You could put a blue card in the bin with the number

reserved written on it. Or, the person who is counting could review the list

of reservations by part number for possible reservations. The person who

is counting will deduct reservations from the number actually counted.

If a system cannot be successfully developed, you may want to adjust On
Hand quantities instead of Available quantities.

Assumption 2: Parts On Priority Orders Have Been Identified.

Parts on Priority Orders will most often have a negative available
quantity. The best place to find all of the parts which are on Priority
Orders is the Print Order Lines Report (X34-7). Run this report before
Inventory Adjustment is started. Then you can resolve most of the
questions while you are doing the Inventory Adjustment job.

The other place to find out is in Parts Inquiry. Parts on finalized Priority

What You Can Do

### What Can Go Wrong And What To Do

When the Available or On hand Quantity is changed on screen, inventory
value is changed accordingly. If the Available Quantity is increased,
inventory value increases because the On Hand Quantity has also
increased. This will be reflected on the Parts End of Day Report and on the
Parts Inventory Pad. This is exactly what you would expect.

The Parts Inventory Pad does not do anything about negative available. It
is concerned with On Hand Quantity. HOWEVER, changing a negative
available to zero is the same as adding to On Hand Quantity, which may or
may not be accurate so take care.

Negative Available Changed to Zero

let's follow one widget again.

Part Had Been Robbed

Robbing parts drives both the On Hand and Available Quantities negative.

looks like this at Parts Inquiry.

When the part is sold, cost is transferred from the General Ledger
Inventory Account to Cost of Sale. The inventory account is decreased by
the cost of the part ($2.00), which may or may not have been included in
the total.

What if this part is included on the Inventory Adjustment Report before

This is correct.

The adjustment is listed on the Parts End of Day Report as an Inventory
Adjustment of +1 at +$2.00.

Now think about the Parts Inventory Pad. In this pure case the General
Ledger Inventory Account exactly matched the cost on the Parts Pad
before inventory. The negative available did not affect the total value
figures. Neither will the zero available or on hand. There are still zero On
Hand. The Parts Pad totals do not reflect the change, but the General
Ledger account does. The audit trail has been broken.

It is not so much that the adjustment process disrupted things. Rather the
habit of robbing parts is not a good one. Hopefully, once inventory is
correct, it can be kept that way with no more robbing.

## CHAPTER X3-7

PRICE UPDATE/PART LISTS MENU

### Introduction

The options on the Automatic Price Update Menu allow you to reprice the
parts in your inventory files when you want to deal with more than one
part at a time. You may update parts according to the most current prices
furnished by the manufacturer, and you may create a price book on your
hard disk.

In the beginning there was a manufacturer who made parts, and there was

a dealer who bought some of the parts. To illustrate this story, P = Part

currently manufactured and carried by the vendor, and d = discontinued
Part.

Manufacturer's parts: PPPPPPPPPPPPPPP
Dealer's parts: PPPPPPP

Manufacturer's price book: PPPPPPPPPPPPPPP
Every dealership had a copy of this book, on paper or on microfiche.
Pretty soon the manufacturer made even more parts, but stopped making a
few parts that the dealer had bought. The discontinued parts were no

Where do price tape update diskettes come from?

‘When manufacturers change the prices on parts, they send a magnetic tape
to DIS. The price tape contains all of the manufacturer's current parts and


X3-7 PRICE UPDATE/PART LISTS MENU [2]

the new prices. The manufacturer uses the price tape to make the price
book (or microfiche). Discontinued parts are no longer listed.

DIS converts the information on the price tape so that it can be used by the
DIS software and sends this information to you on diskettes. The price
tapes take from | to 20 diskettes. Each diskette holds about 14,440 parts,
and even though computers are very fast, it takes a long time to do a price
update on the parts from a major manufacturer.

What to do with the price tape update diskettes (or tape):

1) First, decide whether you'd rather update inventory directly from the
Price tape update diskettes (or tape) or build a price book and then update
inventory from it.

a. From diskettes or tape. Go to Price Tape Update (X37-2) to update
the parts in your inventory files that match parts on the price tape
update diskettes. Choose the device that corresponds to your system:
diskette, magazine, or tape cartridge. Discontinued parts will not be
affected. The price book will not be affected. You can build a price
book later by selecting Create/Update Price Book (X37-4).

b. Build a price book. Go to Create/Update Price Book (X37- 4). There
are 2 options within Create/Update Price Book.

Create a price book. Use the Create option to create a brand new
price book or to replace an existing price book.

Update a price book. Use the Update option to update an existing
price book with supplemental or supersession diskettes only.

Do not use the regular price tape update diskettes, which contain
all of the manufacturer's parts, to update a book, which also

contains all of the manufacturer's parts, unless you have all day to
do it.

The process of creating or updating a price book does not affect the
parts in your inventory files; however, you can use the price book to

update inventory by using Price Tape Update, X37-2. Choose the Price
Book (PB) device.

2) If you keep your discontinued parts in a separate class, you may want

### Supersession

Supersession information is available in the following options:
- Parts Inquiry (X3-1)

- Parts Posting & Maintenance (X3-2)

- Display/Print/Change Price Book (X37-3)

- Point of Sale Detail Line (X5-1)

- Part Availability (Cmd12 from X5-1)

- Electronic Parts Catalogs

Except for Display/Print/Change Price Book (X37-3) and Electronic Parts
Catalogs, backward supersession is not handled. The DIS system attempts
to sell all parts from inventory in a forward chain and displays the last part
in the chain so it can be ordered, if necessary. The Electronic Parts Catalog
skips intermediate parts and displays only | level of backward and 1 level
of forward supersession (the last part in the chain).


X3-7 PRICE UPDATE/PART LISTS MENU [J

Parts Inquiry (X3-1)

The Supersede code "S” means the part has been superseded by a single
part. "M" means the part has been superseded by multiple parts, only the
first (alphabetically) is displayed. This information is updated by price
tape update.

Parts In Inventory

If the entire chain is in inventory, it is displayed at F7=Supersession when
the original part number is entered. If a superseding part is entered, the
chain is displayed from that part forward. You must press F5=Division to
check availability for a part in other divisions.


[| X3-7 PRICE UPDATE/PART LISTS MENU

Parts Not In Inventory

If the original part number is entered, the chain is revealed from the price
book one number at a time in a message at the bottom of the screen. If a
superseding part is entered, the chain is displayed from that part forward.

Parts Posting & Maintenance (X3-2)

Parts In Inventory

Supersession information can be added to any part manuaily. This is
overwritten when inventory is updated from a price tape or price book
unless the part is in a class flagged as non-updatable (automatic pricing =
N) in Configure Vendor/Class (X38-1). In the absence of a price book, this
information is used by POS to chain to superseding parts.

Parts Not In Inventory

Parts may be added from the price book from any point in a chain. No
supersession information is retrieved, only pricing and the return code.
There is no way to know how many superseding parts there are or to go
directly to the end of the chain.

Display/Print/Change Price Book (X37-3)

The price book displays backward (supersedes) and forward (superseded
by) chains. The "M" indicator seems to mean the part supersedes many
different parts and does not correspond to the "M"” indicator used in Parts
Posting & Maintenance, which means the part is superseded by multiple
parts (kit).


X3-7 PRICE UPDATE/PART LISTS MENU [=]

Point of Sale Detail Screen

Point of Sale uses both local inventory and the price book to sell the first
available part in a forward chain, and always displays the last part number
in the chain. A part that has been superseded by multiple parts shows
simply *MULTIPLE*.

Part In Inventory

Availability information is displayed. If the request cannot be filled by the
first part entered, the next part in the chain with available quantity will be
displayed on the comment line. After all available parts have been sold,
the last part in the chain can be ordered.

Part Not In Inventory

Regardless of where you start in a chain, the last part in the chain is
displayed on the comment line. If it is not possible to order the part you
enter, such as AA1117, you will receive an "Invalid part" message, and the
most current part will be displayed on the comment line. If it is possible to
order the part you entered, it will be displayed on the detail line with a "P"
priority code, but the most current part number will be displayed on the
comment line.


X3-7 PRICE UPDATE/PART LISTS MENU C ~

Part Availability

Part in Inventory
All superseding parts in the chain that are in inventory are displayed
whether they will be needed to meet the request or not.

Part Not In Inventory

Part Availability searches local inventory, other divisions, and the price
book. All parts in the forward supersession chain will be displayed. If the
original part requested is in the requesting division's inventory but not
available, it will show "NOT OK." Parts located in the Price book will be
indented and show "NOT OK/PRC BOOK." If you left-justify the parts
and press [Enter] again, the system will search other divisions for the
superseding part and display availability information. You will be able to
order the last part in the chain, if necessary. The system will repeat the
quantity, which is adjusted manually as you decide what parts to sell.

Electronic Parts Catalog

As of 11/5/96, the DIS interface to the parts catalog displays 1 level of
backward supersession and the last part(s) in the forward chain (1 level). If
the parts listed are in the dealer's inventory, availability and bin location
are displayed. No intermediate parts are shown, regardless of whether the
part is in the dealer's local inventory or not. Multiple "Superseded by" part
numbers indicate a kit. Multiple "Supersedes" may be from a kit to one
part or simply separate parts that have been superseded by the same part.

Multiple supersession is the most difficult because manufacturers do not
make it clear whether a part is superseded by 3 different single parts or by
a kit consisting of 3 parts. In some cases, the original part number is


XL


X3-7 PRICE UPDATE/PART LISTS MENU |

superseded by several different part numbers, any one of which can be
used to replace the original part. In other cases, the original part is
superseded by a kit composed of several different part numbers, all of
which are required to do the job of the 1 original part number. In either
case, the DIS Business System displays "*MULTIPLE*" in the "Super."
field at Point of Sale. If possible, use the comment field on the Parts
Posting & Maintenance screen to store all part numbers that are required
for supersession.

Stand-alone parts catalogs (without the DIS interface) display only the last
part(s) in a forward supersession chain.

Considerations - what to think of when setting up

1. Tracking Parts - Nearly everyone has some method of identifying
parts, either on their systems or in their heads. These parts are identified
as obsolete, stocking, non-returnable, eligible for a pre-season order,
etc. These identifications are used for what we call Class Codes.

Class Codes are used by the inventory control system for multiple

purposes. As an example, you could use Class Codes to identify all of

your seeder and tillage parts by identifying each part with the same

class code of X, for spring pre-season. You can use a letter or number

other than X. When you are ready for your large spring pre-season

order to that vendor, you can request a suggested order only for those (
parts with that Class Code. Uses other than suggested orders include

stock returns, parts that you do not want to show on suggested orders

such as obsolete parts, parts grouped by particular pricing levels, etc.

You can always change the Class Code on the part, but if you give it
some consideration now, you will start with a system using all of its
capabilities. Suggested Class Codes are given in a later section of this
handbook.

2. Control vs. Effort - Every company has certain parts of which they do
not maintain accurate records of transactions. They do this because the
costs of maintaining sales history, per piece costing and inventory
listings exceeds the benefit they would derive from knowing this
information. These types of parts typically include nuts and bolts,
washers, and other small items.

Selecting Vendors

From reading the previous section, you probably have selected the vendors
that you want to have on your system. You've probably also given some
thought to the class groupings within each vendor.

This section will help you finalize your selection of major vendors and
short-line vendors. We'll also discuss the effects of grouping short-line
vendors under one vendor code and the meaning of miscellaneous parts.

1. Major Vendors - These are vendors of your major lines of parts. They
will have their own Vendor Codes and several Class Codes. Evaluate
each vendor to determine the Class Codes in which you will categorize
parts and the Order Codes for each of those classes.

2. Short-Line Vendors - These are all of the other vendors from which you

Selecting Classes -

Class Codes are used by the system for suggested stock orders, stock
returns, and stock phase-outs. They are also used to group parts by
mark-up pricing levels. When you determine what classes you wish to
establish, you should take into account the following considerations.

O Do you want the part to appear on suggested stock orders?
0 Do you want to order based on sales history or by assigned minimums
and maximums?

O What pricing bracket does this part fall under? What ranges of dealer
mark-up are you going to establish?

C7 Is this part usually ordered under a special manufacturers program? Do
you get discounts if this part is ordered under a pre-season order or a
ship direct program?

Suggested Classes -
1. Stocking - This class will either have an 'A' or 'C' Order Code.

2. Non-Stocking - This class should have a 'M' Order Code. This class
is also the default class for the vendor. Any new part numbers
added from Point of Sale will be entered into this class and will
remain there until you assign it to another class.

3. New Stock - This class should have either a 'C’ or 'M' Order Code.
Since new parts do not have enough history to use the 'A' Order

Part Number Configuration

‘The purpose of part number configuration is to ensure that the part
numbers you load into the computer match your vendor's price book. This
will result in part reports, such as parts pads, that match the numbering
sequence of your vendor. If your vendor does not provide a price tape,
matching the configuration is helpful when it comes time to manually
update your prices. The part numbers on your system will be in exactly the
same sequence as their new price list.

1. Segment Sizes - Part numbers on the DIS system can be up to 18
characters long. Segment Sizes allows you to break these numbers up
into 1, 2, 3, or 4 segments. Each segment can contain up to 18
characters, but the total for all four segments cannot exceed 22
characters. For example, if we have a 1 segment part number, that
segment can contain up to 18 characters. If we have a 2 segment part
number, the total of the 2 segments cannot exceed 18. One segment
could contain 4 characters and the other 14.

The examples below show an 18 digit part number in one, two, and
four segments.

Segment Sizes

In the example above with four segment parts, there are two part numbers

that are 18 characters long.

The first four segment part is different from the second due to the number
of digits in each segment. To the right of the part number, you will notice
that the total for the four segment sizes is 22. The first part number has 3
digits in the first segment, 7 in the second, 7 in the third and 1 in the last.
The second part has 3 digits in the first segment, and 5 in the next 3. Both
part numbers are 18 characters long. They have only been segmented
differently. The segment sizes were configured to be large enough to hold
the largest possible segment sizes.

Pay particular attention when establishing your Segment Sizes. Unlike
other options in Vendor/Class Configuration, Segment Sizes are extremely
difficult to change.

## CHAPTER X3-11

PARTS END OF YEAR MENU

### Introduction

Parts End of Year Menu contains the options to finish the year for the Parts
Department. LIFO End of Year jobs, X3-i1.2 and X3-11.3 are run

at the end of the fiscal year. Parts End of Year X3-11.1 is run at the
calendar year end.

### Overview

The Parts End of Year Menu contains three jobs:
X3-11.1 Parts End of Year:

Parts End of Year allows you to delete parts sales history that is 24
months or older. It organizes and compresses the parts files. It
builds the history columns (buckets) viewed at Parts Inquiry (X3-1)
and Parts Posting and Maintenance (X3-2) for the next year. This is
a calendar year end job.

X3-11.2 LIFO End of Year: |

LIFO End of Year prints four reports that can be used for tax
reporting. The purpose of the job is to calculate the LIFO value of
your current year's inventory. The value of the current inventory and
previous year's inventory is estimated in base year dollars. A factor
of inflation is calculated and the current dollar value of your
inventory is printed for comparison. This is a fiscal year end job.

X3-11.3 LIFO Setup Procedure:

LIFO Setup Procedure allows you to do the initial setup of the LIFO
files. You will add all parts vendors, enter the base year for


[2] X4-11 PARTS END OF MONTH PROCEDURES C

inventory valuation, and choose the year you need LIFO reports for.
This job only has to be done once. However, if you add new part
vendors, they will need to be added to the LIFO system. LIFO is a
fiscal year end job.

If you want to know more about LIFO, read the following sections
carefully.

### The Theory Of Lifo

When reporting cost of sales for tax purposes, most accountants use the
following formula:

Beginning Inventory + Purchases - Ending Inventory = Cost of Sales (

If it works to your advantage to report a higher cost of sales, therefore
lowering the margins on sales, the LIFO program helps by providing an
estimated LIFO value of the ending inventory for use in the above equation.

LIFO means Last In First Out. In terms of inventory, it means that the last
part added to a part bin cost more than the first part added to that bin. LIFO
assumes that the parts sold have the value of the last part placed in the bin.
A higher cost of sales results. For example, if a part cost $.80 in 1996 and
now the cost is $1.00, LIFO allows the cost of sale to reflect the current
cost of $1.00. This lowers the inventory value and raises the cost of sales,
lowering the sales margins.

There are three reasons that your parts inventory totals could increase
from one year to another:

1. New parts are added to inventory (capital increases).

Co


X3-11 PARTS END OF MONTH PROCEDURES [2]

2. Changes to quantities of parts already on hand (capital increases).
3. Cost increases to inventory (inflationary increases).

What LIFO End of Year does is to wring the inflation out of the parts
inventory total for tax reporting purposes.

Looking at the equation again:
Beginning Inventory + Purchases - Ending Inventory = Cost of Sales

When the accountant is using the LIFO inventory method, the object is to
lower the Ending Inventory figure, thereby raising the Cost of Sales.


[+] X3-11 PARTS END OF MONTH PROCEDURES

Increase (Current Year Dollars).

In 1996, the G/L total would be $9,444.


X3-11 PARTS END OF MONTH PROCEDURES 7]

5,000 (G/L Year End Inventory Value for
1995) plus 4,444 (Capital Increase in Current
Year Dollars in 1996).
The Ending Inventory value for 1996 (G/L
Year End Inventory Value) is $9,444 because
of the LIFO adjustment. Without the LIFO
adjustment the Ending Inventory figure
would be $10,000
In terms of the reporting equation:
Beginning Inventory + Purchases - Ending Inventory = Cost of Sales
In 1996, if you did not use LIFO, the equation would contain the following
figures:
Beginning Inventory + Purchases - 10,000 = Cost of Sales
In 1996, using LIFO, the equation would contain the following:
Beginning Inventory + Purchases - 9,444 = Cost of Sales

The Ending Inventory is lower and the Cost of Sales is higher, reducing
the profit margin on sales.

Using the above formulas, see if you can arrive at the figures used in the
table for 1997 and 1998.

WHAT THE LIFO PROGRAM DOES:

The LIFO program provides LIFO figures for each vendor entered at LIFO
Setup procedure. The parts files are searched. Parts that were in inventory
are examined for cost changes from base year to current year.

The inventory parts are compared to the parts in the LIFO files to calculate
the value of your current inventory in base year dollars. Also, a factor or
percentage is calculated to show cost differences between current and base
year inventory values.

The LIFO files created by the program, u.ILM LIFO Master File and u.JLA

LIFO Detail File (u = your User ID), operate independently of system parts

files. Information stored in the LIFO files is not used to update any other (
parts files.

The LIFO files are large. If you have disk space problems, you may want to
save the LIFO files u.{LM and u.ILA (u = your user Id) on diskette when
you are not using them. You can restore them when you need to use them.

## CHAPTER X3.11-2

### Introduction

LIFO End of Year will print four reports that can be used for tax reporting.
The purpose of the job is to calculate the LIFO value of your current year's
inventory. The value of the current inventory and previous year's inventory
is estimated in base year dollars. A factor of inflation is calculated and the
current dollar value of your inventory is printed for comparison. This is a
fiscal year end job.

Before LIFO End of Year can be run, you must first run LIFO Setup
Procedure (X3.11-3). If you have never setup LIFO, do so before
proceeding. If you have run LIFO Setup Procedure and run it again, the
information for vendors already in the file will be deleted and replaced
with new information.

If you have added any new part lines, the vendors must be added to the
LIFO files before LIFO End of Year will be calculated for those vendors.
If you have not done so, proceed to LIFO Setup Procedure (X3.11-3) to
add new vendors.

If you have any questions regarding the theory of LIFO, refer to Chapter
X3-11, Parts End of Year Menu, The Theory of LIFO,

### Introduction

LIFO Setup Procedure will allow you to do initial setup of the LIFO files.
You will add all parts vendors, enter the base year for inventory valuation
and choose the year you need LIFO reports for. This job only has to be
done once. However, if you add part lines, the vendors will need to be
added to the LIFO system. LIFO is a fiscal year end job.

When you perform LIFO Setup, you choose the year to be used as your
base year. The factor for that year would be 100%. Inventory cost in the
base year is 100% of that year's cost.

The factor for future years will be calculated by the LIFO End of Year
procedure (X3.11-2).

Parts End of Year, The Theory of LIFO.

automatically.

## CHAPTER X3

PARTS OVERVIEW

### Introduction

The Parts Inventory Control Menu is a major functional area of the
integrated DIS System. It features automatic and error free calculations of
part quantities and reports that allow you to see where you are at all times.
In addition, it provides a stock order and receipt system that minimizes
manual work and helps keep your parts stocking levels efficient. When
used with Point Of Sale, information within the Parts System is updated
by transactions during invoicing.

MENU SUMMARIES

X3-1 Parts Inquiry

 

Parts Inquiry allows on-screen viewing of up- to-date information
concerning parts in the DIS System. Information includes
quantities available, reservations, on order and return quantities,
supersessions, sales history and pricing levels.

X3-2 Parts Posting & Maintenance

Parts Posting & Maintenance enables you to make changes to
existing parts or to add new parts to the Inventory Control System.
Many of these transactions, including updates to quantities
available and sales history, are updated automatically from Point
Of Sale Invoicing.

X3-3 Parts Inventory Adjustment Menu

This menu contains jobs which allow you to take physical
inventories on selected ranges of part numbers or bin locations. An
option provides reports of part numbers skipped during the
adjustment process. The Inventory Freeze provides a snapshot of

your parts inventory, which allows you to produce the Variation
Report following physical inventory or price update.

Stock Order Menu

Suggested Stock Orders are calculated according to sales history
and current performance, then are checked and corrected by the
parts manager. Order criteria can be adjusted by the operator.
Order Receipt allows for quick order adjustment for backorders,
overstock and cancelled parts and then prints a report linking
received parts to reservations and optional stocking list. Inventory
is automatically updated.

Stock Return/Phase-Out Menu

Suggested Stock Returns are calculated based on specified
numbers of months of no sales, minimum dollar value of parts and
maximum value of return order. It is manually checked and
corrected by the parts manager. A final report prints for shipment
and record keeping. Retums are automatically posted to inventory
after approval. Phase-Outs work in a similar fashion, but also
removes the part information from the system.

Parts Report Menu

Several managerial reports are available on the Parts Report Menu.
The Parts Management Report provides key decision making
information on inventory activities for each vendor in the System.

All the reports are available at any time and are always up-to-date.

Parts configuration is the key to the DIS Inventory Control System.
The overview in this section will explain some concepts used in

### Establishing Parts Procedures

This section provides some suggestions on establishing procedures for use
by your company's parts department.

System procedures are an important, but often neglected area in the
operations of any computer system. Installing a computer system often
brings integration for the first time to many companies operations. With a
manual system, departments usually work almost independently of one
another. The individual departments are only responsible for providing
other departments with certain bits of information at certain times. A
computer system brings a requirement for integration of information. One
department becomes responsible for the input of certain information
before another department can perform its responsibilities.

Benefits from establishing procedures include:
= Eliminating conflicts on the usage of the system.

= Reducing the time it takes to perform jobs.
= Establishing clear responsibilities so jobs are sure to be performed.

RELEASE 2.1 og


 

### Establishing Responsibilities

Establishing responsibilities allows for defining clear-cut lists of duties for
each person who uses the system. These lists aid in improving the
efficiency of each department's operations.

The primary concern for establishing responsibilities is to make sure that
certain jobs will be performed on the system. Without having
responsibilities defined, you may have duplication of duties or, worse yet,
certain duties for which nobody is responsible.

The first step in establishing responsibilities is to identify what everyone's
current responsibilities are. This can be done by creating a list of each
person's current duties on the system. Once you have created these lists,
any overlaps or gaps in responsibilities will become evident. Correcting
these gaps or overlaps will give you a new list of assigned responsibilities
for each person.


 

### Establishing Procedure Checklists

The primary purpose of establishing procedure checklists is to document
what people have learned about operating the system. Each person who
works with the computer knows certain details of the system operation that
are very valuable to the operations of the company. Documenting the way
you perform certain jobs helps when someone is away due to vacation or
illness and when it comes time to train new employees.

Individuals are sometimes reluctant to share the knowledge they have
about operating the computer. They mistakenly believe that by keeping
this information to themselves, they will enhance or secure their own
positions within the company. This idea is detrimental to both the
individual and the company. For the individual, this means that they can (
never be ill or go on vacation without their work back-logging on their
desks. It also means that they lock themselves into one position within the
company. For the company, it means that they are entirely dependent on
one person to perform certain functions. What if that person becomes ill or
wishes to retire? It also does not allow for any growth paths for people
within the company.

After having established responsibilities from the previous section, you
can now create checklists of all of the identified parts functions on the
system. Each person who has the most experience running certain jobs
should write down each detailed key stroke and decision that they make
when they run a job. After writing down the steps needed to run a job, the
checklist should be checked for accuracy and then given to a person
inexperienced to see if they can actually run the job without error. Collect
these checklists into confidential binders. Access to this information may
have to be controlled if each procedure contains passwords.

RELEASE 2.1 a


 

### Scheduling Jobs

Developing a calendar schedule of jobs to be performed ensures that jobs
will always be run on time and in the proper sequence.

After having examined your individual responsibilities and checklists of
procedures, you can now incorporate all of this information into calendars
of events for your department. This process should be done for each
department using the DIS System. This will ensure that each department
will have a schedule which specifies when jobs need to be run that affect
the schedules of other departments.

Create a schedule calendar by marking a large sheet of paper with blocks
for seven days and four weeks. Within the blocks, write down procedures
on the days that they should be performed along with a primary and
secondary person responsible for running the jobs. You should consider
how certain jobs affect other departments and the sequence in which jobs
should be run.

The critical procedures table and the suggested schedules on the following
pages will help in developing your calendar of jobs.

The most common problem people have with critical procedures is with
the Point Of Sale Posting Batch. We can see from the Critical Procedures
Table that certain jobs must be excluded from the system when this job is
run. Since the posting batch is taking information from all the closed but
not posted documents from the Point Of Sale SAM file, other jobs that
access the SAM file must be excluded. These jobs include Point Of Sale
End of Month, which clears all closed and posted documents and the
Cmd2 - Print and Close procedure from the Point Of Sale Invoicing
program.

Since the Print and Close function of Point Of Sale needs to be excluded,
you either have to train your people not to close documents during the
creation of the posting batch or you need to shut down Point Of Sale
completely. The safest thing to do is to shut down Point Of Sale
completely. Someone may accidentally Print and Close during the batch
creation. If you create the posting batch during the middle of the day, you
may be greatly inconveniencing the parts counter. You need to decide on
the time of day that would least interrupt Point Of Sale activities. Most
users shut down the parts counter right before doing back-up for the
evening. This may be at 4:30 or 5:00.

Some suggested procedures are listed below:

Point Of Sale Posting Batch

{1 Shut down the parts counter at 4:30 or 5:00. Write invoices by hand if
necessary.

QO) Count the till.

O Run back-up without End-of-Day (runs faster).


 

 

Run End-of-Day Procedures (parts and accounting).

0 Hold the print spool for printing the next morning.

 

Run Create Point Of Sale Posting Batch.

 

CQ Review and Post the batch the next morning.

 

 

 

Next moming, have the parts counter recreate manual tickets on the
system if necessary.

 

Handling New Parts
This sequence of steps will ensure that information concerning new parts
will be in the system when needed. (

Many companies have a problem when adding new part numbers to the
system. These are new parts added during Point of Sale or during the
creation of a stock order. When a new part to added to the system, further
information conceming the part still needs to be entered.

What usually happens is that a new part will be added to a stock order. The
order will be finalized and placed with the vendor without anybody
updating the information on the new parts. When the parts are received,
someone will receipt them to the system without updating the information.
When receipted, the parts are ready to sell. When the part number is
requested at Point of Sale, there will be no selling price, bin location or
description. The person selling the part will have to quickly look up the
Price to enter manually on the screen. This will allow him to sell the part
but there will be no costing when the posting batch is processed. The
bookkeeper will then ask the parts department to look up the cost on the
part so the accounting batch can be corrected. After looking up the cost,

RELEASE 2.1 _


 

the parts department will finally update the pricing information in the
system.

The result of this process is more work for everyone.

The following sequence of steps will avoid the selling of parts at Point of
Sale that do not have assigned costs. By updating parts information and
pricing during the creation of the order, new parts will always be ready to
be sold immediately upon the receipt of the order.

From Priority Orders

 

Review the Priority Order. Use the Cmd5 option to update any parts
without price or description.

 

 

 

 

Print the order.

 

O Verify Priority Order for any parts still missing description or pricing.
Update the information at Parts Posting & Maintenance before the parts
are receipted.

 

 

 

When receipting the order, use the Cmd5 option to update
supersessions or any other discrepancies between what was ordered and
received.

 

From Stock Orders

O If any new parts are added manually to the order, use the Cmd5 option
to update any parts without price or description. This will also ensure
valid dollar totals on the printed final order.

 

 

 

Verify the final order for any parts missing description or pricing


 

information. Use Parts Posting & Maintenance to update information
before the parts are receipted.

C1 Upon receipting the order, use the Cmd5 option to update supersession
information or discrepancies between what was ordered and received.

In addition, run the Dealer Net or List Price Missing Report (X36-3) on a
regular basis to check for any parts missing pricing information.
