position 2. Later, if you decide to stop using Target Marketing and turn off
the OPT, the "M" edit code is removed.


[2] X4-10 TARGET MARKETING MENU

### Overview

The Target Marketing Menu contains the following jobs:

X4.10-1

X4.10-2

X4,10-3

X4.10-4

Target Marketing

This job allows you to view and maintain records about
existing and potential customers. Information concerning
your customer's location, previous transactions, unit sales
(whether or not your dealership sold the unit) is made
readily available with this job.

Marketing Information/Call Sheets

This job prints a call sheet for each selected customer.
Each sheet includes information such as the customer's
name, address, phone number, sales-to-date, unit(s), and
topic of call(s).

Marketing Territory Summary Report

This job produces a listing of the name, city, address, phone
number, and date of last call for selected customers.
Customers included in the report can be chosen on the basis
of territory, postal code, city, sales person, and S.LC. code.

Salesperson Itinerary Listing

This job produces a report that includes the name, city,
address, phone number, contact person, topic, date of last
call and call back for selected customers. Customers
included in the report can be chosen on the basis of call
back date, territory, postal code, city, salesperson, and
S.L.C. code.


X4-10 TARGET MARKETING MENU [=]

X4.10-5 Customer Equipment Report
This job produces a listing of the units owned by selected
customers. Each unit's number, make, model, year, serial
number, and purchase date are included in the report.
Customers and units included in the report can be selected
according to a wide range of values.

X4.10-6 Marketing Sales Code Assignment
This job enables you to control which transactions from
Point of Sale and Unit Sales Entry are available to Target
Marketing.

Target Marketing is essentially comprised of three parts.

The first, Marketing Sales Code Assignment (X4.10-6), allows you to
set up which transactions are automatically carried into your Target
Marketing records. Point of Sale (X5-1) and Unit Sales Entry (X22-1)
copy transactions into a file that is used by Target Marketing. You decide
what kind of transactions will be available to Target Marketing by
assigning sales codes (for Point of Sale transactions) and function codes
(for Unit Sales Entry transactions) in Marketing Sales Code Assignment.
Note that this job does work retroactively; if you add a new sales code
today, yesterday's transactions that have that sales code will be available
to Target Marketing.

Target Marketing (the job) is really the workhouse of Target Marketing
(the menu). With this job you can view or modify all of your target
marketing information for any customer. Information such as address,
name, and phone are always displayed on the top of the screen. The
bottom half of the screen can be set to one of four individual modes.

The Customer Information Screen includes contacts, sales reps for
the customer, and the sales history of the customer. Additional

MARKETING


/ LJ X4-10 TARGET MARKETING MENU

fields detail information such as the customer's satisfaction with
your dealership and that customer's interest level. An individual
notebook page is available for this screen for every customer in

your records.

The Call Information Screen is actually a group of related screens,
specifically a group of calls. For the purposes of this screen, a call
represents any single attempt to contact the customer (i.e. by
phone, personally, mailer, etc.) Each call has fields detailing the
interest of the customer, the probability of purchase, call date and
time, call topic, and call method. As the customer is contacted,
individual calls are added or removed from this screen. An
individual notebook page is available for this screen for every
customer in your records.

The Equipment Information Screen, like the Call Information
Screen, can include multiple items. Each unit has its own screen
detailing information such as unit number, type, make, model,
serial number, and year. Additional fields indicate the unit's
condition, the unit's worth, and the unit's seller. An individual
notebook page is available for this screen for every customer in
your records.

The Transaction Screen, like the Call Information Screen, can
include multiple items. Each invoice has its own screen detailing
information such as invoice number, invoice type, amount,
description, and sales representative ID. An individual notebook
page is also available for this screen for every customer in your
records.

The last part of Target Marketing are the four report generators. Each


X4-10 TARGET MARKETING MENU [=]

report has its own emphasis and allows you to select specific customers on
it. Customer Equipment Report, for example, allows you to create a list of
customers who own a specific piece of equipment.

X6.15-2 Backup Electronic Commerce Configuration Files

Use this option to back up your Electronic Commerce configuration files. DIS
Electronic Commerce Manager 400 runs in Library DISFILES, so it doesn’t
interfere with DIS Backup. Since the configuration is not included in DIS Backup,

system initializes the tape and proceeds to back up the EC files immediately.

emergency.

SECTION 1 POINT OF SALE INVOICING

Point of Sale Invoicing provides for:

Counter Tickets
Priority Orders
Rental/Leasing
Service Management
Work Orders

Because of the size and complexity of Point of Sale Invoicing, this chapter
is divided into 3 sections. Section 1 covers Point of Sale screens and its
basic features. Section 2 covers the multitude of advanced features that are
available within Point of Sale, including electronic parts catalogs. Section
3 covers Service Management, which can be purchased separately.

Unlike they are in other jobs, the command key options are not always
listed at the bottom of Point of Sale screens; however, you can press the
[Help] key ([Alt]+[F1] in Client Access) to see what command keys are
available. The command keys are described in the discussion of the Sold
To screen.

The default is "Y" (Yes) for back order parts to be printed on the

Recalling a Held Document

To recall a document, simply leave the first line on the Entrance screen
blank and use the customer index, which will be followed by the
document index. If you prefer, you can bypass the index screens by
entering a document number.

For a unit, you can begin with the unit number and go to the document
index, or use the unit number and document number together to go
directly to the detail screen.

Reopening a Closed Document

A document can be reopened as long as it hasn't been posted. Follow the
instructions provided in the previous paragraph for recalling a held
document. A document can be opened only from the Sold To screen. Press
[Cmd7] to return to the Sold To screen, then press [Cmd9] to reopen the
document.

Changing from CHARGE to CASH

DIS encourages you to open all documents for charge customers as charge
documents by using their names instead of the CASHd customer. If you
do this, you can change the document to a CASH document and back to
CHARGE; however, documents that are originally opened as CASH
cannot be changed.

To change a charge document to cash, you must be on the Sold To screen,
which means that you may need to press [Cmd7]. On the Sold To screen,
press [Cmd5]. For documents originally opened as CHARGE, [Cmd5]
serves as a toggless, which can be used at any time.

Quotes

Quick quotes can be made from the Part Availability screen. See
[CMD12]-PART AVAILABILITY later in this section. Quotes are easily

### Command Keys

You can press [Help] to see the valid command keys, which are described
in a little more detail below.

Cmd1-End job
Available at the Entrance screen only. Ends Point of Sale Invoicing and
returns to the Point of Sale Menu.

Cmd2-Print and Close
Closed documents can be recalled and reopened until they are posted.
Closed documents are usually included in the next Point of Sale
Posting Batch (X55-1). Documents are always printed at the time they
are closed.

RSF=R __If there is periodic invoicing, the rental status is changed

from AV=Available to RE=Rented.

RSF=U The line on the document in periodic billing, which refers
to the unit rental, is deleted, and if it is the only line, the
entire document is deleted. The unit's status changes to
AV=Available.

RSF=B No changes.

Cmd3-Print and Hold
The document is printed and held as an open document, which can be
recalled and changed as often as necessary. Many dealerships open
work orders, enter notes concerning the work to be done, get the
customer to sign the printed copy, and place the electronic copy on
hold. The shop can recall the document to add parts and labor as the
work proceeds.

Cmd4-Hold
Holds the open document without printing.

Cmd5-Charge/Cash Toggle SOLD TO SCREEN ONLY
The charge/cash toggle is used to change a charge document to a cash
document. The document must be opened as a charge and then changed
to cash. It can be changed back to charge. If the document is opened as
acash document, you cannot toggle to charge. First press [Cmd7] to
return to the Sold To screen, then press [Cmd5].

Cmd6-Delete Line
Available on the detail screen only. See also “Changing a Line," which
is discussed later in the section on DETAIL LINES.


14 X5-1 « POINT OF SALE INVOICING RELEASE 2.2

Cmd7-Retum to the Sold To Screen
To reduce the possibility of error, you must make a conscious effort to
return to the Sold To screen before you void a document or reopen a
closed one.

Cmd8-Add to End
When you are add parts or labor to a long repair order, press [Cmd8] to
go to the end of the document.

Cmd9-Reopen document SOLD TO SCREEN ONLY
To reopen a document which has been closed, but not posted, first press
[Cmd7] to return to the Sold To screen, then press [Cmd9]. The
document is marked "REOPENED."

the rental sales flag is changed to B=Bypass: no changes
will be made when the document is closed.

will be made when the document is closed.

RSF=B —— No changes.

Cmd10-Cancel/Void SOLD TO SCREEN ONLY

To cancel or void a document, first press [Cmd7] to return to the Sold (
To screen, then press [Cmd10]. A confirmation message is displayed.
A copy of the document is printed. The document number will appear
on the Voided Documents Report, which is printed when a Point of
Sale batch is created (X55-1).

Cmd12-Part Availability

Cmd13-Recap
Provides a summary the amounts being charged and credited on the
document: a breakdown of parts sales, minus the discounts, plus the
tax less prepayments and a document total.

### Parts Search Window

Evoke the Parts Window by putting a "?" in the "Part Number" field on
the detail screen. You may perform a positional search by part number by
entering a text string after the "?”. Besides the fact that the text string
begins with a "2" the resulting search would be equivalent to a search by
part number detailed below.

Once the Parts Search Window is displayed, you can perform a search by
part number by entering a text string and press [Enter]. You will be
positioned in the Parts Index to the first part that begins with text string
you just entered (positional search). Alternately, if you precede the text
string with a "*" the computer will display all parts that contain the text
string you entered in any position (non-positional search). For example
"*10" would find 10551, 911002, and, 6510.

You may also perform a search by description. This works in the same
way as the parts search, except that [Cmd5] and not [Enter] is pressed
once the text string has been keyed in.

Work Order List

A work order list can be printed for any open Point of Sale document. It is a list of
the available parts in order by vendor and part number. The work order list is
printed on a invoice form and looks exactly like the invoice without labor,
miscellaneous parts, unit sales, etc. Only parts in inventory are listed. (See also,
Pick List and Warranty Claim List.)

Pick List

A pick list can be printed for any open Point of Sale document. It is a list of the
available parts in order by bin location, which makes it easier to gather the
necessary parts, especially for long work orders. The pick list is printed on an
invoice form and looks exactly like the invoice without labor, miscellaneous
parts, unit sales, etc. Only parts in inventory are listed. (See also, Work Order List
and Warranty Claim List.)

Warranty Claim List
The Warranty Claim List is similar to the Work Order List in that parts appear in

order by bin location; however, cost is printed instead of list price. See also, Work
Order List and Pick List.

### Cmd12-Part Availability

A REAL TIME SAVER, especially for work orders and quotes, the Part
Availability screen makes it possible to check the availability of a lot of parts very
quickly and transfer them directly to a Point of Sale document. You can reach the
Part Availability screen from an open document or directly from the Point of Sale
Entrance screen. You can even open a new document from Part Availability,
eliminating the need to return to the entrance screen or to rekey the parts.

The Part Availability screen accommodates 10 part numbers, which may be
regularly stocked parts that are in your inventory files, parts that are in a price
book, or brand new part numbers. Parts that are located in a price book and brand
new part numbers can be added to the sales document and to your inventory files
from Part Availability. Supersession is checked even if master information on the
part is not provided by the manufacturer. See also, Adding Parts from Point of
Sale.

The parts search window is available from Part Availability by typing a question
mark (?) in the part number field. Bearing Interchange information is available by
typing a pound sign (#) in the part number field. See Parts Search Window.

Adding Parts From Point of Sale

When a customer needs a part that you don't stock, you can add the part number
to a Point of Sale document, to your inventory files, and place it in the priority
order queue, all at the same time. The procedure depends on whether you are
adding from the detail screen or from the Part Availability screen and whether
you are adding from a price book or not.

Detail Screen With a Price Book

To add a part to a document and to your inventory files from a price book, follow
these steps.

On the parts format detail line, type the part number and press [Enter]. If the
part is located in a price book, the message, "Part found in price book," is
displayed. The system places a "P" in the field labeled "Pty" (Priority), which
means that the part will be placed in the priority order queue. For more
information, see the section on Priority Orders, which is presented later.

O Press [Enter] again to add the part to the document. Information about parts
located in a price book, is added to the document and to your parts inventory
files. The part is added as 1 segment, left justified.

O Check the "Add Parts Segmentation" report at Parts End of Day, and correct
the segmentation in Parts Posting & Maintenance (X3-2). It is important to
make these corrections daily; otherwise, these parts may cause errors in other
parts jobs that depend on proper segmentation.

Without a Price Book

To add a part to a document and to your inventory files without a price book,
follow these steps.

O On the parts format detail line, type the part number with its segment markers.
The segmentation must conform to what is set up for the vendor in
Vendor/Class Configuration (X38- 1). It may help to look at a Configuration
Report (X38-2). For more information about segmentation, see CHAPTER
X3-2, PARTS POSTING & MAINTENANCE.

Templates

The Copy-Lines function plus a little creativity on your part will enhance
productivity enormously. You can create templates (quotes) for all sorts of things:
kits, standard jobs, winter tune-ups, paint jobs, oil changes, or any combination of
parts and labor that are usually sold together. Remember, quotes will not have any
effect on your inventory.

You could set up a "fake" customer (or unit) where the quotes are held. As the
quotes are established, you can use the P.O.# field on the Sold-To screen to enter
a short description, which will be displayed at the document index at Point of
Sale.

As an extra shortcut, use the Letter Writer (X4-5) to establish a list of the
documents and tape the letter where it will be accessible to Point of Sale users or
print copies of the quotes and organize them in a notebook.

The Copy-Lines process can be used to copy as many templates (source
documents) as you want into the same target document.

CREDIT CARDS C

Introduction

DIS has developed software that accommodates all types of credit cards at Point
of Sale Invoicing. Transactions can be electronically transmitted to First Data
Resources (FDR) in Omaha, Nebraska, which is a clearinghouse that processes
credit applications, authorizes and processes transactions, and bills customers
monthly. To accomplish the electronic transfer, a DataTran device, which requires
an additional COM port, is used. If you are interested in purchasing a DataTran
device, contact your DIS Marketing Representative.

FDR assigns Merchant Ids and authorizes dealerships to submit transactions for
the credit cards they plan to accept. In addition to major credit cards, FDR handles
private-label credit cards, such as Case Credit and New Holland, which are
handled like any other credit card. The dealership receives a remittance for the
amount of the transaction, less the discount, within 48 hours.

On the Sold To screen at Point of Sale Invoicing, a “Credit Card" field will be

displayed when a document is opened to a receivable customer. It is available for (
charge and cash documents and will not be visible on internal documents, quotes,
standard jobs, or history documents. When a credit card code is present and the
document is closed, the Credit Card Authorization screen is displayed. In this

chapter, you'll learn how to enter the credit card type and how to use the

authorization screens, which are different for electronic and manual authorization.

You'll learn how to charge a portion of the total and accept cash for the rest.

 

 

 

NOTE:
For credit cards that have been set up with FDR, transactions can be pre-
authorized. To do so, it is necessary to press F2=Close and Print to reach

the authorization screen; however, when a pre-authorization is requested,
the document is not closed. After the pre-authorization is complete, you'll
be returned to the document detail screen and the document can then be
held.

 

If the DataTran device is powered off, it must be reset or the background job must
be canceled.


POINT OF SALE X5-1 » POINT OF SALE INVOICING 43

### Warning!

If there is a problem with electronic authorization and your terminal locks
up, wait for the program to time out (about 3 minutes); otherwise, your files
may lock up. Do not do a System Request to terminate the job.

 

Setup Overview

All credit card sales, including private cards, require the same setup. Here are the
steps:

1) Account Maintenance (X14-2). Decide on a general ledger account for the
card.

2) Receivables Maintenance (X11-2). Create a receivables address number for
the card.

3) Credit Card Maintenance (X52-14). Set up a code and description for the
card and enter its receivables address number. If you don't have a DataTran
device or if the card has not been set up with FDR for electronic transmission, set
EDC Capable=N.

4) Receivables Maintenance (X11-2). Optional. Enter credit card information for
each customer and select a default to be used at Point of Sale Invoicing.

5) Credit Code Maintenance (X68-1). Optional. Set up a credit code to flash a
message at Point of Sale alerting salespeople that a customer needs to fill out a
credit card application.

In addition, two other setup options are required for a DataTran device:

6). EDC Configuration (X52-15) and Installation of the DataTran Device.
Configuration is an option on the Table Maintenance Menu. You'll use it to set up
merchant Ids assigned by FDR, establish a cutoff time for transaction batches, and
change or add promotion codes and specify a default promotion code. An
installation diagram is at the end of the chapter.

Error Recovery. For your convenience, error recovery procedures related to the
DataTran device can be found at the end of this chapter and in EDC Configuration
(52-15).

What You Need to Know About Credit Card Transaction Batches

When you are using a DataTran device, there are 3 distinct batches of credit card
transactions, which may or may not contain the same individual transactions:

1) On the DIS system, the Point of Sale posting batch includes credit card
transactions,


44 X5-1 # POINT OF SALE INVOICING RELEASE 2.2

2) On the DIS system, the FDR batch includes credit card transactions that have ‘a °
been transmitted to FDR.

3) On the FDR system, there is a batch of credit card transactions that have been

received and are settled at 6:00 P.M. Central time.

As credit card transactions are automatically authorized and transmitted using the
DataTran device, they are listed in an open FDR batch on the Baich List screen in
Transmit Credit Card Transactions (X55-5). This is not the same as the Point of
Sale batch: it contains only credit card transactions that have been closed and
transmitted to FDR. There is a similar batch at FDR. The FDR batch is
automatically settled by FDR at 6:00 P.M. Central Time. The time that batches
are cut off on the DIS system (settle time) should be set to coincide with FDR's
settlement. Settle time is entered from the Merchant ID maintenance window in
EDC Configuration (F14 from X52-15).

If there have been manually authorized transactions, you'll use Transmit Credit
Card Transactions (X55-5), to send them to FDR and make them a part of the
current FDR batch.

Also, you can use option X55-5 to display and print batches, and move a

transaction to a different batch when you're reconciling your statement from FDR.

A transaction could end up in different batches on the FDR and DIS systems if the

DIS system clock is slightly different from the one at FDR. In addition, if a batch

is ever out of balance, which is unlikely, it can be recalculated using option X55- (
4.

24-hours a day. It is started for the first time by going into Point of Sale. The only
time you need to be concerned about stopping it is to reset the DataTran device,

### Dropship Orders

A dropship order is a special case of a priority order. Priority orders are discussed
in a separate section, which you may want to review if you need more

 

information.

Note:
The order number for a dropship is the same as its Point of Sale document
number.

 

 

A dropship order is opened to the customer as usual. On the Sold To screen, enter
the appropriate information in the area labeled "Ship To."

A priority order that is shipped directly from the manufacturer or vendor to the
customer is a "dropship." Only inventoried parts can be handled by the dropship
process; that is, a part that has a part number in your inventory files, whether you
regularly stock the part or not. Dropship parts are placed on Point of Sale
documents by using a detail line with a parts format, and by placing a “D"
(Dropship) in the field labeled “Pty.”


64 X5-1 « POINT OF SALE INVOICING RELEASE 2.2

### Electronic Parts Catalogs

The DIS Seamless Interface provides easy Windows access to data in the DIS
Business System and electronic parts catalogs. The interface is the software that
enables you to use inforrhation from your inventory files and from an electronic
parts catalog (EPC) at the same time.

Part information from the catalog, such as the description, is displayed along with
information from your files, such as pricing, bin location, and on hand quantity, if
the part is already in inventory.

You can tell where the part was located by looking at the bin location. If the part

### Labor Costing C

This feature allows you to record the exact cost associated with sales of labor at
Point of Sale. The expense associated with the cost of labor can be reflected in the
cost of sale account.

For actual costing, the system multiplies the rate of pay for an employee by the
hours reported for the labor. The result is debited to the labor cost of sale account
with the labor sales.

### Priority Orders

The discussion in this section provides only a brief overview. Priority orders are
covered in detail in CHAPTER X5-3, PRIORITY ORDERS. Also, CHAPTER
X3-3, PARTS INVENTORY ADJUSTMENT MENU, provides a lot of
information about the basic assumptions underlying the DIS Business System and
its handling of parts inventory. Dropship sales, which are a special case of Priority
Orders, are discussed in a separate section of Section 2 — see Dropship Orders.

The DIS Business System tracks priority (emergency) orders with maximum
efficiency. By taking time to understand how they are handled, you can eliminate
a lot of list- keeping and notes to yourself about who needs what. You can also
save money by shifting parts from priority orders to stock orders whenever you
can.

When you enter a part number on a parts detail line (format=P), the system checks
the quantity that is available for sale. The available quantity is different from the
on hand quantity. For example, there may be 3 parts on hand, but 2 of them may
be reserved for other Point of Sale documents; therefore, only 1 is available.

When a customer needs a part that is not available or not normally stocked (not in
your inventory files), the system redisplays the detail line and places a "P" in the
field labeled "Pty." The line is not placed on the document until you press [Enter]
a second time, which provides an opportunity for you to decide how to handle the
situation.

Valid Order Codes

You may, of course, accept the line by pressing [Enter], or you may want to
replace the "P" with any valid order code from the list following:

D= Dropship

L=Lost sale

P = Priority order

Q=Rob a prior reservation and order the part

R = Rob a prior reservation and do not order

S = Place the part on a stock order

On the document, the order code appears in the column on the left, which is
labeled "TDP" (Tax, Discount, Priority).

Clone Documents

The part is placed in the order queue as soon as the document is closed or placed
on hold. If the document is closed, a clone document is created. Clone documents
are easy to spot because their number is the same as the original document with
an alphabetical character at the end. For example, a counter ticket CTO0805 is

cloned to CTOO805A. If CTOO805A is closed before all orders have been filled, it { ~~
is cloned to CTOO80SB, etc.

QUANTITY BREAK PRICING Co

What is Quantity Break Pricing?

Many manufacturers receive quantity break pricing from their suppliers, price
breaks for buying in volume. The price depends upon the quantity. For example,
there may be one price if they buy from 1 to 9 of an item, and a lower price if they
buy 10 or more, and an even lower price if they buy 50 or more. There may be
several ranges with corresponding price decreases. Manufacturers may choose to
pass these savings on to the dealers. Dealers, in turn, may want to pass the savings
on to customers who buy in large quantities.

Advantages of Quantity Break Pricing

Selling parts in large volumes helps to reduce your costs. The parts do not have to
be counted or handled as often. Storage costs are decreased. Up front, the parts
may not cost as much because of the large quantity discounts received from the
manufacturer.

What is required
A price book with quantity break pricing is required. Quantity break pricing is
furnished by some manufacturers, usually on a separate price tape. (

Identifying the Customers

You can identify the customers who buy in volume on their master records in
Receivables Maintenance (X11-2). The default, which is "N," is automaticaily
displayed at Point of Sale where it can be changed.

Identifying the Parts

The price tape sent by the manufacturer will identify parts with quantity break
prices and the breaks offered on specific quantities (ranges). A "Y" appears on the
Parts Posting & Maintenance screen in the field labeled “Qty Break" during Price
Tape Update. [f you want a part to be considered for quantity break pricing at
Point of Sale, change this field to "N."

Quantity break pricing information is kept in the price book, not in your inventory
files. If the price book is removed, quantity break information will be lost.

At Point of Sale

On the Sold To screen, the field labeled "Quantity Break Pricing" displays "Y" or

"N" from the customer's master record (Receivables Maintenance, X11-2). You

can change the default, making Quantity Break Pricing available on a document- ‘oe


POINT OF SALE X5-1_¢ POINT OF SALE INVOICING 79
OO EY SALE INVOICING 7D

by-document basis. Changing the default at Point of Sale has no effect on the
customer's master record; it does make it possible to offer special pricing ona
document-by-document basis.

After you press [Enter] to go to the detail screen, the system records your choice
for quantity break pricing (Y or N). If, after adding parts to the document, you
return to the Sold To screen, you can change from "Y" to "N" or vice versa. Parts
that are already on the document are not affected; however, parts added after the
change are priced accordingly. By changing the field on the Sold To screen at the
appropriate time, you can control quantity break pricing line-by-line if necessary.

Stocked Parts:

When Quantity Break Pricing=Y on the Sold To screen, parts sold on the detail
screen are checked in the price book to determine the range and price that applies.
The system calculates the extended price by muitiplying the quantity break price
by the quantity sold. If the parts are in stock and available, they are added to the
invoice. If a portion is unavailable, the line is redisplayed with a "P" in the field
labeled "Priority." To add the parts to the priority order queue and place them on
the document, where they show as "ORDERED," simply press [Enter].

Audit Procedures

Your Parts End of Day reports provide important audit information that should be
checked on a regular basis. (Yes, you need to READ them!) Quantity Break
Pricing presents an unusual opportunity for unscrupulous employees to take
advantage of the system, but the evidence will appear in black and white on the
End of Day Audit Report. A typical case is described below.

If an invoice is opened with an "N” in the Quantity Break Pricing field, the parts
on the invoice will be priced as normal. Assume the customer pays cash for these
parts.

Later, if the invoice is reopened, the Quantity Break Pricing field could be
changed to "Y." The lines could be brought down and changed for quantity break
pricing and re-entered.

The total on this invoice, which will be included in the Point of Sale Batch, will
be different from the one given to the customer. At best, the cash drawer will be
over the difference. At worst, someone could have pocketed the difference.

To guard against this kind of error, the End of Day Audit Report should be
reviewed each day. The section to check is “Changes to Quantity." which is sorted
by vendor, then by part number.

### Supersession

Supersession information is available in the following options:
- Parts Inquiry (X3-1)

- Parts Posting & Maintenance (X3-2)

- Display/Print Price Book (X37-3)

- Point of Sale Detail Line (5-1)

- Part Availability (Cmd12 from X5-1)

- Electronic Parts Catalogs

Except for Display/Print Price Book (X37-3) and Electronic Parts Catalogs,
backward supersession is not handled. The DIS system attempts to sell all parts
from inventory in a forward chain and displays the last part in the chain so it can
be ordered, if necessary. The Electronic Parts Catalog skips intermediate parts and
displays only 1 level of backward and 1 level of forward supersession (the last
part in the chain).

Parts Inquiry (X3-1)

The Supersede code “S” means the part has been superseded by a single part. “M”
means the part has been superseded by multiple parts, only the first
(alphabetically) is displayed. This information is updated by price tape update.

Parts In Inventory

If the entire chain is in inventory, it is displayed at F7=Supersession when the
original part number is entered. If a superseding part is entered, the chain is
displayed from that part forward. You must press F5=Division to check
availability for a part in other divisions.

Parts Not In Inventory
If the original part number is entered, the chain is revealed from the price book
one number at a time in a message at the bottom of the screen. If a superseding
part is entered, the chain is displayed from that part forward.

Parts Posting & Maintenance (X3-2)

Parts In Inventory

Supersession information can be added to any part manually. This is overwritten
when inventory is updated from a Price tape or price book unless the partis ina
class flagged as non-updatable (automatic pricing = N) in Configure Vendor/Class
(X38-1). In the absence of a price book, this information is used by POS to chain
to superseding parts.


92 X5-1 ¢ POINT OF SALE INVOICING RELEASE 2.2

 

 

Parts Not In Inventory (—

Parts may be added from the price book from any point in a chain, No
supersession information is retrieved, only pricing and the return code. There is
no way to know how many superseding parts there are or to go directly to the end
of the chain.

Display/Print Price Book (X37-3)

The price book displays backward (supersedes) and forward (superseded by)
chains. The “M” indicator comes from the manufacturer and means the part
supersedes many different parts and does not correspond to the “M” indicator
used in Parts Posting & Maintenance, which is created by Price Tape Update (or
manually) and means the part is superseded by multiple parts (kit).

Point of Sale Detail Screen

Point of Sale uses both local inventory and the price book to sell the first available
part in a forward chain, and always displays the last part number in the chain. A
part that has been superseded by multiple parts shows simply *MULTIPLE*.

Part In Inventory

Availability information is displayed. If the request cannot be filled by the first
part entered, the next part in the chain with available quantity will be displayed on
the comment line. After all available parts have been sold, the last part in the
chain can be ordered.

Part Not In Inventory

Regardless of where you start in a chain, the last part in the chain is displayed on
the comment line. If it is not possible to order the part you enter, such as AAI1I7,
you will receive an “Invalid part” message, and the most current part will be
displayed on the comment line. If it is possible to order the part you entered, it
will be displayed on the detail line with a “P” priority code, but the most current
part number will be displayed on the comment line.

Note:

 

 

 

   
  
  

You'll be informed about supersession on the availability line. In some
cases, you'll need to delete a priority order line and add the part number
displayed under "Super." To make it convenient to add supersession parts,
the availability line remains even after a line is deleted.

 

Part Availability

Part in Inventory

All superseding parts in the chain that are in inventory are displayed whether they
will be needed to meet the request or not.

Part Not In Inventory

Part Availability searches local inventory, other divisions, and the price book. All
parts in the forward supersession chain will be displayed. If the original part
requested is in the requesting division’s inventory but not available, it will show
“NOT OK.” Parts located in the price book will be indented and show “NOT
OK/PRC BOOK.” If you left-justify the parts and press [Enter] again, the system
will search other divisions for the superseding part and display availability
information. You wil] be able to order the last part in the chain, if necessary. The
system will repeat the quantity, which is adjusted manually as you decide what
parts to sell.

Electronic Parts Catalog

As of 11/5/96, the DIS interface to the parts catalog displays 1 level of backward
supersession and the last part(s) in the forward chain (1 level). If the parts listed
are in the dealer’s inventory, availability and bin location are displayed. No
intermediate parts are shown, regardless of whether the part is in the dealer’s local
inventory or not. Multiple “Superseded by” part numbers indicate a kit. Multiple
“Supersedes” may be from a kit to one part or simply separate parts that have
been superseded by the same part.

Multiple supersession is the most difficult because manufacturers do not make it
clear whether a part is superseded by 3 different single parts or by a kit consisting
of 3 parts. In some cases, the original part number is superseded by several
different part numbers, any one of which can be used to replace the original part.
In other cases, the original part is superseded by a kit composed of several
different part numbers, all of which are required to do the job of the 1 original
part number. In either case, the DIS Business System displays "*MULTIPLE*” in
the "Super." field at Point of Sale. If possible, use the comment field on the Parts

supersession.

Stand-alone parts catalogs (without the DIS interface) display only the last part(s)

### Transferring Parts Between Divisions

In this section, you'll lear 3 methods for transferring parts to other divisions from
Point of Sale: 1) Simple Sale, where the receiving division is treated exactly like
any other customer, and the parts are considered "sold." 2) Order & Transfer,
where parts are recorded as "transferred" to the receiving division, which creates
and receives a priority order for the parts. 3) Menu option X3.12-1, Transfer
Parts.

Simple Sale

In this case, one division simply sells parts to a division in exactly the same way it
would sell parts to any other customer. This method is satisfactory when very few
parts are involved and no change in stocking levels is required. Accounting
transactions are generated in the transferring (source) division by the invoice. A
journal entry is required to receive the parts into inventory in the receiving
division.

Oi Set up a system address for the receiving division in Receivables Maintenance
(X11-2).

O Use Price Table Maintenance (X52-9) to establish default pricing if it is
different from Dealer List. See CHAPTER X52-9, PRICE TABLE
MAINTENANCE.

O Open the Point of Sale document to the receiving division and proceed as
usual.

Order and Transfer

In this case, the division that needs parts (receiving division) creates a priority
order, which is filled by the division that has the parts available (transferring
division). The transaction is recorded as a “transfer,” instead of a "sale." This
method is more appropriate when many parts are involved and some change in
stocking levels would be appropriate. Accounting transactions are generated by
invoices in both divisions; however, a journal entry is required to receive the parts
into inventory in the receiving division just as any other order requires.

Procedures for the receiving division and the transferring division are described
separately.

Receiving Division
The receiving division needs the parts to complete a sale to a customer. The
sales document is handled exactly the same as for any other sale.
O Open a sales document to the customer.

come from the other division are not available, they will be placed on the
document with a "P" in the column labeled "TDP." When the document is
closed or placed on hold, the parts will be included in the priority order
queue.

O Finalize the priority order in the Priority Orders job (X5-3). On the sales
document the "P" changes to a "p."

1 Send the priority order to the division that has available parts. See
“Transferring Division,” which follows.

O When the parts are received, use Receive Order (X342-2) to receive the

priority order. On the sales document, the "p" changes to an "a," which
means that the parts can now be sold to the customer.

Transferring Division
The first 2 steps for the division that has available parts are the same as for the
simple sale described above.
O Set up a system address for the receiving division in Receivables
Maintenance (X11-2).

O) Use Price Table Maintenance (X52-9) to establish default pricing if it is
different from Dealer List. See CHAPTER X52-9, PRICE TABLE
MAINTENANCE.

The next steps record the parts as “transfer sales" on the Parts Management

Report (X36-2) and stop sales history update.

{1 Open the Point of Sale document to the receiving division.

lines on which the field "I/W"="I" are charged to this address. If the
document is opened to a unit, leave the field blank if you want all internal
charges to go to the unit.
Unit #: If the customer bought the unit from you or if you use the DIS

labeled "Warranty Address #." Detail lines on which the field "I/W"="W"
are charged to this address.

Detail Screen

On the detail screen, lines that display the "I/W" field are eligible for split billing.
One line can be charged to one address; therefore, to charge the customer for ¥2 of
the labor and absorb the other / as an internal charge, 2 lines are necessary.
When the field labeled "I/W" is left blank, the charge goes to the customer (or

unit).

When a work order is closed, as many as 3 separate documents, all with the same
document number, may be printed.

Customer Document
A document will always be printed for the customer even if all the charges
were Warranty and Internal. The customer's address and name appear the top
of the document. All detail lines appear on the document; however, the total
reflects only what the customer owes. The extended amounts on the Warranty
and internal lines are marked “N/C" (no charge).

Internal Document

When the document was opened to a customer, an internal document is printed
only if the field labeled "I/W"="I" on one or more detail lines. The address
number at the top of the document will be the Internal Address # or Unit #
charged. If the "Internal Address #" field contained a valid address number on
the Sold To screen, that Internal Address # will be charged. If the "Internal
Address #" field was blank, and the “Unit #" field contained an Unit number,
that unit number will be charged.

Warranty Document

A warranty document is printed only if the field labeled "I/W"="W" on one or
more detail lines. The address number at the top of the document will be the
Warranty Address # selected in the “Warranty Address #" field on the Sold To
screen.

STANDARD JOBS Cc

Inquire/Update Job Codes has been eliminated: standard jobs are created in Point
of Sale Invoicing where they have the same format as work orders. Standard jobs
can be copied to work orders (active documents), other standard jobs, and history
documents. By reviewing work orders, you can identify lines that should be set up
as standard jobs in order to eliminate repetitive typing.

As a standard job is created, it is associated with a group code and identified as a
Group:Job. Service tables can be constructed by selecting Group:Job
combinations. When a unit is associated with a table, the Group:Job combinations
are automatically selected in Recommended Maintenance. In addition, any
Group:Job can be added to Recommended Maintenance.

Organization

You can organize standard jobs in a way that is most convenient for your
dealership. In many cases, it is more practical to set up recommended
maintenance by make/model and series code than by make/model and year.

To help you understand the concepts introduced in this release, a consistent (
example using group and table codes of 5000 is provided. You'll see how standard

jobs are associated with this code at Point of Sale. Then you'll learn how to create

a service table for recommended maintenance by selecting standard jobs from the

group.

In the unique groups, which pertain to different make/models, jobs will be similar
and should follow a similar naming pattern, such as OILCHG (Oil Change) or
WINTER (Winterization). By maintaining a consistent naming convention, you
can easily remember how to locate a particular job in any group. This is
particularly true if you use numerical codes. For example, Job 1 for Group 6600
(6600: 1) and Job 1 for Group 7000 (7000:1) may be for an oil change, even
though the jobs require different parts and labor.

Using the same name for the group and table makes it easy to set up
recommended maintenance. Remember, groups are used at Point of Sale; tables
are used for Recommended Maintenance. Any Group:Job combination can be
added to the Recommended Maintenance screen. Also, any Group:Job
combination can be copied at Point of Sale.

SECURITY MAINTENANCE

### Introduction

A Division is usually a store. Security Maintenance allows you to add or
delete a division. Information associated with each division such as name
and address, security, etc is changed or supplied in Security Maintenance.
Master Security for the entire system can be changed in Security
Maintenance.

     

Note:

 
 
 

  

The master security screen, where division codes are established, also
controls the order in which divisions are processed by jobs which
affect more than one division, such as End of Day (X1-9) and
Combined End of Month Procedure (X1.10-2).

   
   

 
 

 

### Setting Up Master Security

Master Security is used to gain access to the division code information.
This is the main security code. With use of this code, any other
security information becomes available. Only persons with the highest
security level should be given this code.

## CHAPTER X6-1

BACKUP & RESTORE FILES MENU

### Introduction

Options on the Backup & Restore Files Menu enable you to back up your
dealership's files and run divisional end of day jobs at night after everyone
is off the system. The automated backup runs Communications End of
Day for Case, during which the prices of Case/IH parts that were inquired
on during the day are updated (if they are in an updatable class).

[| X6-1 BACKUP & RESTORE FILES MENU

Overview of Menu Options

Immediate Backup

An immediate backup is appropriate if you want to do a critical job, such
as monthly billing, in the middle of the work day. If a critical job is
already underway, immediate backup cancels itself; if not, the system
checks for active jobs and gives you a chance to ask people to sign off or
cancel the jobs manually. Although you may select immediate backup to
tape and initialize the tape at the same time, you will probably want to
request backup to disk and move it to tape later. A dedicated system is
required only during the backup to disk. Work can continue as backups are
moved to tape.

Work with Automated Backup Schedules

Use this option to schedule backups for each file set and end of day jobs
for each division. It is not necessary to repeat this initial setup work unless
you want to change the schedule or you add another division and need to
schedule end of day jobs for it.

Create Daily Backup Tapes

Use this option to initialize and label tapes that will be used for daily
backups. You may create tapes for as many days as you need. You will be
prompted to insert the next day's tape. You may use this option to create
backup tapes to replace ones you want to keep, such as the backups that
follow Monthly Billing, Accounting End of Month, or End of Year.

Restore from Backup

Use this option to restore a file set from disk or tape. The DIS Backup
system keeps a log of all backups that have ever been done and what
happened to them, whether they are on disk, tape, or have been deleted and
are unavailable. If the backup you want is on disk or tape, it can be


X6-1 BACKUP & RESTORE FILES MENU [= |

restored.

Altention! Customers who have used previous versions of the DIS
Business System: Restoring data files no longer involves deleting the file
set you are currently using; in fact, the option to Delete Data Files has
been disabled. If you need to remove a file set, such as Z-files
permanently, the Response Line can help you.

Restoring a file set is as simple as selecting the backup from a list in
Restore from Backup.

As long as you find out before the next backup, you can "undo" the
restore. Before a file set is restored, the system backs up the current file
set as an "Undo" save file and leaves it on the disk until the next regularly
scheduled automated backup. If you have restored the wrong backup or if
you simply want to return to the current data after running some reports
from an old backup, all you do is press a function key. See F10-Undo
Restore.

 

Work with Backups

Work with Backups maintains a log of all backups and where they are
(disk, tape, deleted, etc.). From this log, you can select any backup on disk
and delete it or move it to tape. Backups to disk are not deleted until they
are moved to tape or manually deleted. /t is important to be aware of
backups on disk and deal with them in a timely manner to prevent
problems with disk space.

Prepare Tape for Backup

You can save time by using this option to initialize tapes to have on hand
when you need to do an immediate backup.

No jobs that use data files can be running during the DIS Business System
backup. The SupportPRO business system interface (BSI) is such a job

Job active for each SupportPRO client. Every night before you leave,

the PC at the end of the day, follow the instructions for exiting (

in the ABC group, and double-click on it. The SupportPRO application
will start.

### Security & Setup

The Backup security code is required for all options on the Backup &
Restore Menu. Since daily backups are automated, no security is required.

Setup work is minimal and consists of the following steps:

1) Use option 3, Create Daily Backup Tapes, to initialize and label tapes
that will be used for daily backups. Tapes are labeled MONDAY
through SUNDAY.

2) Use option 2, Work with Automated Backup Schedules, to select the

file set(s) you want to backup, a time, persons who will be notified to
insert the backup tapes, etc.

3) Also, in Work with Automated Backup Schedules, you will schedule

End of Day jobs by division. End of Day jobs are done after backup
and include:

Accounting End of Day. A S/36 printer ID can be designated.
Parts End of Day. A S/36 printer ID can be designated.

Index Rebuild. Indexes are rebuilt for the file set. If they have
already been run when the system processes a division, they will
not be run again. The following indexes are rebuilt: Marketing,
Point of Sale, Receivables, and Vendor.

4) If you want to initialize and label a tape to have on hand for immediate
backups, use option 6, Prepare Tape for Immediate Backup. Tapes can
be initialized at the time you do an immediate backup; however, it
makes the backup less immediate.

COMMON QUESTIONS & ANSWERS

What's the Best Thing About Backup?

Backup is always done to disk first, provided there is enough space. An
immediate backup to disk takes about 10-20 minutes for an average file
set, and this is the only time you need a dedicated system. After that, the
backup can be moved to tape manually, which takes longer but does not
interfere with other work.

L


X6-1 BACKUP & RESTORE FILES MENU |

What Happens to Active Jobs?

Backup does not proceed as long as there are active jobs. Since there is
always a possibility that somebody will forget to sign off, you can set up
backup to warn users every 2 minutes and cancel active jobs after 10
minutes. Bear in mind that there is always a danger of losing valuable
data when jobs are canceled. See also the section on Case
Communications & Backup, which appears earlier in this chapter.

SECURITY & CONFIGURATION


X6-1 BACKUP & RESTORE FILES MENU co

What's the Most Important Thing to Remember?

Put the right tape in the tape drive every night.

Reliable backups are your best insurance against disaster. Several
conditions govern successful backups. Assuming that critical jobs have
ended, the following conditions must be true for a successful backup:
i) A tape must be placed in the drive.

2) It must have the correct label.

3) The tape drive must be working.

If even one of these conditions is not true, the system backs up to disk,
provided there is enough room.

Are Backups to Disk OK?

Yes and no. Backups on disk are condensed and disk space will not
normally be a problem; however, old backups are not deleted
automatically. If backups are allowed to accumulate on your disk,
performance may suffer. At 90% of disk capacity, the system skips the
disk backup and attempts to back up to tape. If for any reason, the tape
backup is unsuccessful, you are left with no backup at all.

It is your responsibility to move disk backups to tape as soon as possible.

Backups are deleted as soon as they are successfully moved to tape or
when you manually delete them using the option, Work with Backups.

RELEASE 2.2 LL


X6-1 BACKUP & RESTORE FILES MENU [=]

If Backup Fails, What Do | Do?

Backup fails completely only when there is no available disk Space and no
tape or the wrong tape in the drive. First, move all old backups to tape in
Work with Backups. As they are moved to tape, backups are deleted from
the disk. If there are no backups on disk, find out what's wrong and free
space somehow. Make sure the correct tape is placed in the tape drive
before the next scheduled backup.

Which Tape Do | Use?

Backup uses a 24-hour clock (military time). Noon is 12:00; midnight is
24:00. Backup time is from 8:01 on the first day until 8:00 the next day.
The system expects Monday's tape from 8:01 A.M. on Monday until 8:00
A.M. on Tuesday. Files on backup tapes are active for 7 days. If active
files are found, backup will append (add to the end) the next backup.
After 7 days, the system will re-initialize the tape with the same label.

Examples. If backup time is scheduled for 23:59 on Monday, the system
expects Monday's tape and backs up Monday's data at one minute until
midnight. If backup is scheduled for 2:00, the system expects Monday's
tape and backs up Monday's data at 2:00 Tuesday morning. At 8:01
Tuesday morning, the system expects Tuesday's tape. If backup is
scheduled for 14:00 and it is Tuesday, the system expects Tuesday's tape.

SECURITY & CONFIGURATION


X6-1 BACKUP & RESTORE FILES MENU Co

What If I Forget the Tape?

Provided there is enough room, the DIS Backup System always backs up
to disk first. The disk backup is deleted only after backup to tape is
successful. If you fail to put in the tape, or if it is the wrong one, a backup
will be done to disk; however, you should move it to tape as soon as
possible.

How Will | Know If Backup is Not Successful?

When backups fail, messages are sent only to the 2 user profiles set up in
Work with Automated Backup Schedules (X61-2) and not to all
workstations. Messages received alert you to the following conditions: (

1) The wrong tape was in the drive and the system backed up to disk only.
Move the backup to tape ASAP using option 5, Work with Backups.

2) The system could not back up to disk, but backup to tape was
successful. This means your disk is over 90% full, and you need to free
some space ASAP. Failure to do so may impact performance. In
addition, if the system cannot back up to disk or tape in the future,
backup will fail completely.

3) Backup failed completely: no room for a backup to disk and no tape or
the wrong tape in the drive (or the tape drive is not operating).

How Do | Delete & Restore?

The option to Delete Data Files has been disabled. If you need to remove a
file set, such as Z-files permanently, the Response Line can help you. With
the new backup, restoring a file set is as simple as selecting the backup

RELEASE 2.2 LU


 

from a list in Restore from Backup. The DIS Backup system keeps a log
of all backups that have ever been done and what happened to them,
whether they are on disk, tape, or have been deleted and are unavailable.
If the backup you want is on disk or tape, it can be restored.

WARNING! If a backup appears in the list with a blank File Location
(neither On Tape nor On Disk), it could be incomplete and should not be
testored.

What if | Restore the Wrong Backup?

As long as you find out before the next backup, you can "undo" the
testore. Before a file set is restored, the syste backs up the current file
set as an "Undo" save file and leaves it on the disk until the next regular
backup. If you have restored the wrong backup or if you simply want to
return to the current data after running some reports from an old backup,
all you do is press a function key.

SECURITY & CONFIGURATION

### Technical Notes

Work with Backups is a log which lists all backups with the most
recent first. The list is maintained indefinitely, and there is currently no
way to remove items.

When backups are saved to disk, dealer files are saved in a special
library, DISSAVLIB. The files are deleted when they are moved to
tape; otherwise, they accumulate until the disk is full.

When a file set is restored, the current file set is saved temporarily in
DISSAVLIB but the files are deleted at the next backup.

following order:

### Introduction

DIS provides several options for some applications. These options have
been combined and grouped by application on the OPT DIS Master Menu.
When you select an application, such as Receivables, the options that are
available are listed on the screen.

To find out more about an option, type the number of the option, and press
the [Help] key. To return to the menu, press [Enter]. In this chapter you'll
find each menu followed by the help screens for each option.

When option switches are set in the DIS Library, they apply to all
divisions. In every case, the first option is the default: the standard
configuration for the DIS Library. You do not need to set any switches if
you prefer the first option. To print a list of your switch settings, use the
OPT Report (X6-13) in the DIS LIBRARY.

### How To Run

From the Security & Configuration Menu (X6), select option 3, OPT DIS
Master Menu. If you know exactly where you want to go, you can “menu
hop” by typing the nearest menu, such as X631, which is the General
Ledger Menu.

INTRODUCTION CC® PSO file,

Time Clock is a software solution for tracking time and billing charges. It is
available as an additional product, which can be purchased separately from DIS.
If the Thermo King dealer OPT (X63B-6) is on, Thermo King job codes are
available and work the same as in Point of Sale. Because of its enhanced features
and reporting ability, Thermo King dealers are encouraged to use Time Clock
instead of Technician Time Card Entry.

Time Clock is a punch-out system with full reporting capabilities. To make it easy
to upgrade, Technician Time Card Entry looks and feels like Time Clock’s
Review by Technician except that it does not use work type codes, status codes,
or technicians’ profiles. Technician Time Card Entry and Time Clock are
mutually exclusive; that is, if Time Clock has been installed, Technicians Time
Card Entry is not available and vice versa.

By simulating a time clock on the AS/400, it provides the following functions:

=  Validates and accumulates job information

= Keeps an unlimited amount of history making it easy to compare productivity
in Different years

= Requires minimal disk space: 5 MB per year for 10 technicians, each with 5
work orders and 4 miscellaneous punches, working 6 days/week

- Describes work by status codes and work type codes, both of which are
completely user-defined and can be tailored to your work environment

= Automatically charges overtime on selected work types (optional)

= Start/end of day can be customized for each technician's schedule

= Provides a "window" or grace period during which a punch is the same as the
start/end time of day

- Directly linked with Point of Sale Invoicing with command key that goes to
Review by Work Order

- Places billable labor lines on Point of Sale work orders when you press
[Enter] in Time Clock

= Allows management to review charges by technician/date or by work order

® Provides excellent management reports

- Includes an option to print one Time Clock audit report at Accounting End of
Day

= Protects integrity of reports by disabling labor lines at Point of Sale, but
provides access if necessary See CHAPTER X5.11-3, CONFIGURATION.

= Provides access to Thermo King job codes just like in Point of Sale provided
the Thermo King dealer OPT (X63B-6) is on.

Point of Sale

Billable Time Clock entries are placed directly on Point of Sale documents when
[Enter] is pressed in Time Clock, Review by Technician and by Work Order.

Because the integrity of Time Clock Reports will be compromised if labor lines
are entered through Point of Sale, they are disabled when Time Clock is installed.
From time-to-time, it may be necessary for someone to enter a labor line from
Point of Sale; therefore, a process has been provided whereby Point of Sale access
can be unlocked for one or more users. See POS Access Lock in CHAPTER
X5.11-3, CONFIGURATION.

 

### Warning

To ensure the accuracy of Time Clock reports, make sure all labor lines that are
entered at Point of Sale are duplicated in Time Clock. Better yet, don't use labor
lines at Point of Sale at all.

Thermo King Job Codes

Time Clock follows the same specifications and limits for creating Thermo King

warranty claims as in Point of Sale Invoicing, which are:

> One claim per work order

» Each claim can contain multiple segments (one segment only for a “Service
Parts Only Claim”)

» One cause of failure (COF) per segment

Up to 27 part lines per segment (one part line only for a “Service Parts Only

Claim”)

Up to 9 Misc. parts per claim

Up to 3 outside invoices per claim

Up to 10 comment lines per claim

Command key option from Point of Sale

From the detail screen at Point of Sale Invoicing (X5-1), [Cmd14] takes the user
directly to the labor lines for that work order in Time Clock's Review by Work
Order option, where lines can be changed (for a more thorough discussion, see the
heading Review by Technician or Work Order). Pressing [Cmd1] returns to Point
of Sale.

Punch-out

Time Clock is a “punch out" system. After an employee "punches" in,
subsequent entries describe the activity (work, lunch, break, etc.) that has just
been completed. Time Clock automatically calculates the time that has elapsed
since the previous entry. In the review options, Time Clock will calculate the
punch-out time of day if the time reported is furnished, or hours reported if the
punch-out time of day is furnished.

Review by Technician or Work Order

Jn Review by Technician, new time data can be added to a technician's day ora
whole day can be entered; however, in Review by Work Order, labor lines cannot
be added or deleted--they can only be changed to billable or non-billable. Lines
can also be changed to internal or warranty provided there is an internal or
warranty address on the Sold To screen at point of sale.

Review by Technician is for a specified date. All punches made by the technician
for that date are displayed; therefore, the reviewer is working with consecutive
time periods for the technician's day.

By contrast, Review by Work Order shows all labor lines for all dates and all
technicians on a selected work order. Lines are displayed in the same order as
they appear on the point of sale detail screen. Additions, deletions, or changes to
time would affect the technician's time on other, unidentified work orders;
therefore, they are not allowed. Lines can be changed from billable to
non-billable, which deletes them from the work order, but does not delete the time
from the technician's day, and the lines can still be seen in Review by Technician.


6 X5-11 » TIME CLOCK MENU RELEASE 2.2

Work Status Codes & Work Type Codes

Technicians' work is described by work status codes, such as Break, Lunch,
Repair, Diagnostics, Waiting for Parts, Job Complete. It is further defined by
work type, such as Regular, Welding, etc. These codes are completely
user-defined and should be tailored to your work environment.

### Warning

Once work status codes and work type codes
have been set up and are in use, they should not
be changed, because to do so alters historical
data.

 

 

Overtime

Automatic overtime can be specified for any work type, such as Regular or

Welding. When this type of work is done outside of normal working hours, the

default start/end of day or the individual technician's start/end of day, the

technician's overtime rate is charged automatically. It is possible to designate a

"window" during which a punch is considered the same as the start/end of day. a
For example, you can specify a window of 10 minutes, which means that if the

normal start of day is 8:00 a.m., any punch from 7:50 to 8:10 would be the same

as 8:00 a.m. The window prevents many small overtime charges due to slight

variations in punch-in and punch-out times.

Service Management
Only the time and billing charges that are posted to work orders become part of
service history.

Reports
An audit report is printed at Accounting End of Day. In addition, audit

reports, which focus on technicians, work orders (same as the End of Day
Report), or date and time, can be requested at any time.

History

Time Clock entries accumulate indefinitely, but it requires minimal disk i

## CHAPTER X5.11-3

### Configuration

### Introduction

Use this option to configure default values for Time Clock to use, including
starting and ending times for a typical day, and selection of a Time Clock report
that will be printed when Accounting End of Day is run. Configuration can be at a
company level or customized for individual divisions.

This ‘option is also used to grant or remove access to Point of Sale labor lines.
Because the integrity of Time Clock Reports will be compromised if labor lines
are entered through Point of Sale, they are disabled when Time Clock is installed.
From time-to-time, it may be necessary for someone to enter a labor line from
Point of Sale; therefore, a process has been provided whereby Point of Sale access
can be unlocked for one or more users.

Usually, a particular user will be granted permission enter labor lines at Point of
Sale to meet an emergency, and then it will be revoked. See POS ACCESS
LOCK.

 

### Warning

To ensure the accuracy of Time Clock reports, make sure all labor lines that are
entered at Point of Sale are duplicated in Time Clock. Better yet, don't use labor
lines at Point of Sale at all.

## CHAPTER X5.11-5

REVIEW BY WORK ORDER

### Introduction

This option, which is similar to Review by Technician, is used to review billing
and make sure that charges accurately reflect the work that was done. This
function is not available to most technicians—usually only the parts manager or
accounting staff are allowed to review or change time clock data. It can be
accessed by way of the Time Clock Menu or by pressing [Cmd14] from the detail
screen at Point of Sale Invoicing (X5-1), which takes you directly to the detail
screen of labor lines for the current work order.

Charges are placed directly on point of sale documents directly from this job.
Nothing is posted to the general ledger until the work order is closed and posted.
Default labor sales codes set up in Configuration for customer, internal, or
warranty labor are used.

Lines cannot be added or deleted in Review by Work Order; however, some
changes can be made to individual punch-out lines. Lines can be changed to
billable or non-billable. Lines can be charged to internal or warranty provided the
respective internal or warranty addresses are entered on the Sold To screen of the
work order. Hours Reported cannot be changed because doing so would impact
technicians' time on other, unidentified work orders.

The following fields can be changed without deleting and re-entering lines in this
job:

## CHAPTER X5.11-4

REVIEW BY TECHNICIAN

### Introduction

This option, which is similar to Review by Work Order, is used to review billing
and make sure that charges accurately reflect the work technicians have done
before work orders are closed and posted. This function is not available to most
technicians—usually only the parts manager or accounting staff are allowed to
review or change Time Clock data. If the Thermo King OPT is on (X63B-6), the
Review by Technician screen displays job code fields, which are illustrated on
page 12.

In this job, as opposed to Review by Work Order, one technician's time is
displayed for a selected date for all the work orders that technician works with on
that day. Consecutive time periods that make up the technician's entire day are
displayed in order by punch-out time to make it easy to see how the day was
spent. Lines can be added, deleted, and changed.

Charges are placed on the point of sale documents directly from this job;
however, nothing is posted to the general ledger until the document is closed and
posted.

Changes can be made to individual punch-out lines, or a day's entries can be
created. The default labor sales codes set up in Configuration for customer,
intemal, or warranty labor are used. Shortcuts expedite the process. For example:
if you enter the elapsed time, the system can calculate the punch-out time, or if
you enter the punch-out time, the system can caiculate the elapsed time. The
following fields can be changed without deleting and re-entering lines in this job:
= Time Clock status code

Time Clock work type code

Field (Y/N)

Hours Reported and Hours Billed

Rate

Tax and discount codes

Billing entity (Customer, Internal, Warrantor, or Non-billable)

Comment
Thermo King job code (available only if the Thermo King dealer OPT (X63B-
6) is on).

encouraged to use Time Clock instead of Technician Time Card Entry.

### "Warning

An initial punch-in at the start of each day is required. At least one punch-out is
expected before the next punch-in. After midnight, a new punch-in is required.

 

 

### Punching In

When a technician arrives, their first action is to punch in by typing IN at the
Work Order prompt. For User ID TCLOCK, a verification message follows. For
other User IDs, a time prompt, which defaults to the current system time, is
presented before the verification message.


POINT OF SALE X5.11-1 ¢ TIME CLOCK 5

After punching IN, a technician is expected to punch out at least once before
another punch-in will be accepted. After midnight, a new punch-in is required.
See below.

After Midnight

If technicians work past midnight, they need to punch out before midnight or ask
management to make a correction on the following day.

Technicians will not be allowed to punch out after midnight without first
punching IN for the new day.

PUNCHING OUT

Punching Out After Breaks Or Lunch

When technicians return from breaks or lunch, they do not use a work order
number or unit number. They should simply press [Enter] at this prompt and to
proceed to the next prompts to record the break or lunch time, which has just been
completed.

y% Punching Out Before Breaks Or Lunch

When technicians stop working to go on breaks or to lunch, they will use a work
order number or unit number. After entering the work order or unit number for the
job they have been working on, they press [Enter] to proceed to the next prompts
to record the type of work they have been doing. Work orders can be selected
from the Work Order Index, which is described below.

Punching Out To Change Jobs

When technicians go from one job to the next, they enter the work order or unit

Multiple Punches to the Same Job Code

Thermo King’s flat rate is intended to apply to the entire work order, regardless of
how many times it is necessary to use the same job code when the work is done
over several days. For each new entry, Time Clock searches the work order for
other occurrences of the same job code. Then the billed hours of each line are
adjusted so the total billed hours exactly equal the flat rate for the job code. The


POINT OF SALE X5.11-1 © TIME CLOCK 18

calculation uses each line’s reported hours and assigns billed hours based on its
percentage of total reported hours.

Multiple Job Codes

Sometimes job codes cover very small tasks, and it is inefficient to punch out for
each one; for example, a task may actually be made up of several individual steps,
each with its own job code, but it is impossible to separate them into their own
time segments. In this case, Time Clock Entry (X5.11-1) allows up to 5 job codes
per punch.

There is no way for Time Clock to “know” how many job codes you want to
combine; therefore, it is necessary to “reserve” the lines. To indicate that there
will be 5 job codes, enter a character on each line, as illustrated below.

After the punch-out process is complete, Time Clock must assign hours reported
to each job code. The assumption is that the job code with the largest number of
billed hours should have the largest number of reported hours. The flat rates of all
job codes are added and each job code is assigned a percentage based on the total
elapsed time. Then Time Clock checks the work order. If it finds the same job
codes already on the work order, billed hours are adjusted so the total billed hours
exactly equal the flat rate for the job code. The calculation uses each line’s
reported hours and assigns billed hours based on its percentage of total reported
hours.

Muitiple Job Codes with Overtime

When a technician punches out using multiple job codes after the end of their
normal day, Time Clock records regular time first, then uses overtime on the last
job code. Billed hours are allocated as described in the previous section, Multiple
Job Codes.

TECHNICIAN TIME CARD ENTRY

### Introduction

Technician Time Card Entry (TTCE) is a modified program from Time Clock
(Review by Technician). This program can be used as a punch-out system (just
like Time Clock); however, its purpose is not to account for every minute of a
technician’s time. The purpose of Technician Time Card Entry is to record

 

 

 
  
 

billable hours.

### Overview

Labor lines added in TTCE update Point of Sale documents immediately, and
lines can be changed as long as you don’t end the job. The price for this is that
there is no provision for deleting a batch; rather, lines must be deleted
individually. After the job is ended, existing labor lines can be modified only on
the work order. New labor lines can be entered in Technician Time Card Entry or
at Point of Sale. With Time Clock, on the other hand, labor lines cannot be added
or modified at Point of Sale.

An Options window, which can be displayed at the beginning of each session,
retains Time Card settings.

If a batch ends abnormally, simply re-select the Time Card option (X5-10) and
the previously entered data will be recovered automatically. See Automatic
Recovery on page 17.

 

### Warning!

Technician Time Card Entry will always assign the maximum billable hours to (
a job code every time it is used; therefore, on the work order, you may find the
job has been over-billed and will have to be adjusted.

 

 

Technician Time Card Entry has no reporting capability of its own, but the Labor
Analysis Report can be used to check technicians’ hours. It is not connected with

Technician Time Card Entry and Time Clock are mutually exclusive; that is, if
Time Clock has been installed, Technician Time Card Entry is not available and
vice versa.

If the Thermo King dealer OPT (X63B-6) is on, Thermo King job codes are
available and work the same as in Point of Sale. Because of its enhanced features
and reporting ability, Thermo King dealers are encouraged to use Time Clock
instead of Technician Time Card Entry.

You can change the way the system rounds. In Point of Sale, you’re allowed only

hours, or to the nearest tenth, quarter, or hundredth of an hour plus 10 min. (1), 30

will not be re-edited and re-rounded until you bring them down to the detail line.

 

### Notice

stick with it. Although it’s possible to change the way rounding is done, even
mid-session, it is not a good idea. Changing rounding methods may confuse the
customers and make the resulting work orders and reports difficult to reconcile.

### Introduction

The Service Management System (SMS) is an additional product, which is
available for purchase. With it, you can create service work orders and
automatically record and track detailed service history for each unit. You can
store standard jobs, with parts, labor, and description, ready to add to a customer's
service work order as a complete job. In the most advanced usage, the system will
compare the service history of a unit to the recommended service table, and
recommend tasks that should be performed. You may then add other jobs to the
list to be performed, all of which are recorded in detail, to the unit service history.

Fleet Management is compatible with the Truck/Van Inventory Additional
Product. Its primary focus is the management of scheduled maintenance for
customers who own fleets of equipment located at different sites. Fleet
Management makes it possible to schedule maintenance by date or hourmeter and
to charge against a pre-established contract for maintenance. .

 

NOTE
L Unique serial numbers are required for both SMS and Fleet Management.

### Service Management System Features

Your Service Management System is fully integrated with Point of Sale, Parts,
Accounts Receivable and the General Ledger. SMS provides 2 sessions at Point
of Sale. A command key toggles back and forth between 2 documents.

At Point of Sale, the following types of documents (modes) are available, all
with the same "look and feel":
— Active documents (work orders)
— Standard jobs
— History documents, including:
a) Closed & posted work orders with serial numbers (former active
documents)
b) Documents created expressly for history records, created at POS in
"History documents" mode

Standard jobs

Standard jobs can be created directly or copied from work orders and
accumulated over time. Standard jobs, each identified as a Group:Job, can be
added to Service Tables and Recommended Maintenance. As the Group:Job
identifier is expanded to its actual detail lines on a work order, the usual
checks are made for special pricing, supersession, availability, etc. (same as
Copy-Lines).

Labor lines shortcut

When a standard job is used on a work order, a job code entered on the POS
Entrance screen takes you directly to a labor line on the detail screen. From
there you can add labor and other types of lines, and then close the work
order.

Customer's unit number

You can use the customer's unit number to locate the unit more quickly at
POS or Inquire/Update Service Units. It is also printed on the work order.
Series code

Equipment can be identified by a 3-characier series code, which may often be
more helpful than organizing service tables strictly by make/model and year.
Reports on the Service Reports Menu can be displayed on screen or printed.
Equipment searches by:

— Customer name

License number

Unit number

Serial number (same as VIN). Must be unique.

— Customer's unit number

Service history tracking including all work performed on equipment. Detail
can be preserved as long as you need it (or disk space permits), then collapsed
in stages.

Equipment is automatically added to the service system when it is sold.
